title: Baltimore
text:
Baltimore ( , locally: ) is the <a href="List%20of%20municipalities%20in%20Maryland">most populous city</a> in the <a href="U.S.%20state">U.S. state</a> of <a href="Maryland">Maryland</a>, as well as <a href="List%20of%20United%20States%20cities%20by%20population">the 30th most populous city</a> in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, with a population of 585,708 in 2020. Baltimore was designated an <a href="Independent%20city%20%28United%20States%29">independent city</a> by the <a href="Constitution%20of%20Maryland">Constitution of Maryland</a> in 1851, and today is the largest independent city in the United States. As of 2017, the population of the <a href="Baltimore%20metropolitan%20area">Baltimore metropolitan area</a> was estimated to be just under 2.802 million, making it the <a href="List%20of%20metropolitan%20areas%20of%20the%20United%20States">21st largest metropolitan area</a> in the country. Baltimore is located about northeast of <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, making it a principal city in the <a href="Baltimore%E2%80%93Washington%20metropolitan%20area">Washington–Baltimore combined statistical area (CSA)</a>, the third-largest <a href="combined%20statistical%20area">CSA</a> in the nation, with a calculated 2018 population of 9,797,063.
Prior to <a href="European%20colonization%20of%20the%20Americas">European colonization</a>, the Baltimore region was used as hunting grounds by the <a href="Susquehannock">Susquehannock</a> <a href="Native%20Americans%20in%20the%20United%20States">Native Americans</a>, who were primarily settled further north than where the city was later built. Colonists from the <a href="Province%20of%20Maryland">Province of Maryland</a> established the <a href="Port%20of%20Baltimore">Port of Baltimore</a> in 1706 to support the <a href="tobacco">tobacco</a> trade with Europe, and established the Town of Baltimore in 1729. The first printing press and newspapers were introduced to Baltimore by <a href="Nicholas%20Hasselbach%20%28printer%29">Nicholas Hasselbach</a> and <a href="William%20Goddard%20%28publisher%29">William Goddard</a> respectively, in the mid- 18th century.
The <a href="Battle%20of%20Baltimore">Battle of Baltimore</a> was a pivotal engagement during the <a href="War%20of%201812">War of 1812</a>, culminating in the failed <a href="United%20Kingdom%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20Ireland">British</a> bombardment of <a href="Fort%20McHenry">Fort McHenry</a>, during which <a href="Francis%20Scott%20Key">Francis Scott Key</a> wrote a poem that would become "<a href="The%20Star-Spangled%20Banner">The Star-Spangled Banner</a>", which was eventually designated as the American national anthem in 1931. During the <a href="Baltimore%20Riot%20of%201861">Pratt Street Riot of 1861</a>, the city was the site of some of the earliest violence associated with the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>.
The <a href="Baltimore%20and%20Ohio%20Railroad">Baltimore and Ohio Railroad</a>, the oldest railroad in the United States, was built in 1830 and cemented Baltimore's status as a major transportation hub, giving producers in the <a href="Midwestern%20United%20States">Midwest</a> and <a href="Appalachia">Appalachia</a> access to the city's <a href="Port%20of%20Baltimore">port</a>. Baltimore's <a href="Inner%20Harbor">Inner Harbor</a> was once the second leading <a href="port%20of%20entry">port of entry</a> for <a href="immigrant">immigrant</a>s to the United States. In addition, Baltimore was a major <a href="manufacturing">manufacturing</a> center. After a decline in major manufacturing, <a href="heavy%20industry">heavy industry</a>, and restructuring of the <a href="Rail%20transportation%20in%20the%20United%20States">rail industry</a>, Baltimore has shifted to a <a href="service%20economy">service-oriented economy</a>. <a href="Johns%20Hopkins%20Hospital">Johns Hopkins Hospital</a> and <a href="Johns%20Hopkins%20University">Johns Hopkins University</a> are the city's top two employers. Baltimore and its surrounding region are home to the headquarters of a number of major organizations and government agencies, including the <a href="NAACP">NAACP</a>, <a href="ABET">ABET</a>, the <a href="National%20Federation%20of%20the%20Blind">National Federation of the Blind</a>, <a href="Catholic%20Relief%20Services">Catholic Relief Services</a>, the <a href="Centers%20for%20Medicare%20%26amp%3B%20Medicaid%20Services">Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services</a>, and the <a href="Social%20Security%20Administration">Social Security Administration</a>.
Many of Baltimore's neighborhoods have rich histories. The city is home to some of the earliest <a href="National%20Register%20Historic%20District">National Register Historic District</a>s in the nation, including <a href="Fell%27s%20Point%2C%20Baltimore">Fell's Point</a>, <a href="Federal%20Hill%2C%20Baltimore">Federal Hill</a>, and <a href="Mount%20Vernon%2C%20Baltimore">Mount Vernon</a>. These were added to the <a href="National%20Register">National Register</a> between 1969 and 1971, soon after historic preservation legislation was passed. Baltimore has more public statues and monuments per capita than any other city in the country. Nearly one third of the city's buildings (over 65,000) are designated as historic in the National Register, which is more than any other U.S. city.
History.
The city has 66 <a href="National%20Register%20Historic%20District">National Register Historic District</a>s and 33 local historic districts. Over 65,000 properties are designated as historic buildings and listed in the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places%20listings%20in%20Baltimore">NRHP</a>, more than any other U.S. city. The historical records of the government of Baltimore are located at the <a href="Baltimore%20City%20Archives">Baltimore City Archives</a>.
Etymology.
The city is named after <a href="Cecil%20Calvert%2C%202nd%20Baron%20Baltimore">The 2nd Baron Baltimore</a>, an <a href="Anglo-Irish%20people">Anglo-Irish</a> member of the <a href="Irish%20House%20of%20Lords">Irish House of Lords</a> and founding proprietor of the <a href="Province%20of%20Maryland">Province of Maryland</a>. "Baltimore Manor" was the name of the estate in <a href="County%20Longford">County Longford</a> which the Calvert family, <a href="Baron%20Baltimore">Barons Baltimore</a>, owned in <a href="Ireland">Ireland</a>. "Baltimore" is an <a href="anglicization">anglicization</a> of the <a href="Irish%20language">Irish</a> name "Baile an Tí Mhóir", meaning "town of the big house".
Native American settlement.
The Baltimore area had been inhabited by <a href="Native%20Americans%20in%20the%20United%20States">Native Americans</a> since at least the <a href="10th%20millennium%20BC">10th millennium BC</a>, when <a href="Paleo-Indians">Paleo-Indians</a> first settled in the region. One Paleo-Indian site and several <a href="Archaic%20period%20in%20North%20America">Archaic period</a> and <a href="Woodland%20period">Woodland period</a> archaeological sites have been identified in Baltimore, including four from the <a href="Late%20Woodland%20period">Late Woodland period</a>. In December 2021, several Woodland period Native American artifacts were found in <a href="Herring%20Run%20Park">Herring Run Park</a> in northeast Baltimore, dating 5,000 to 9,000 years ago. The finding followed a period of dormancy in Baltimore City archaeological findings which had persisted since the 1980s. During the Late Woodland period, the <a href="archaeological%20culture">archaeological culture</a> known as the Potomac Creek complex resided in the area from Baltimore south to the <a href="Rappahannock%20River">Rappahannock River</a> in present-day <a href="Virginia">Virginia</a>.
In the early 1600s, the immediate Baltimore vicinity was sparsely populated, if at all, by Native Americans. The Baltimore County area northward was used as hunting grounds by the <a href="Susquehannock">Susquehannock</a> living in the lower <a href="Susquehanna%20River">Susquehanna River</a> valley. This <a href="Iroquoian%20languages">Iroquoian-speaking people</a> "controlled all of the upper tributaries of the Chesapeake" but "refrained from much contact with <a href="Powhatan">Powhatan</a> in the <a href="Potomac%20River">Potomac region</a>" and south into Virginia.
Pressured by the Susquehannock, the <a href="Piscataway%20tribe">Piscataway tribe</a>, an <a href="Algonquian%20languages">Algonquian-speaking people</a>, stayed well south of the Baltimore area and inhabited primarily the north bank of the <a href="Potomac%20River">Potomac River</a> in what are now <a href="Charles%20County%2C%20Maryland">Charles</a> and southern <a href="Prince%20George%27s%20County%2C%20Maryland">Prince George's</a> counties in the coastal areas south of the <a href="Atlantic%20Seaboard%20fall%20line">Fall Line</a>.
Colonial period.
<a href="European%20colonization%20of%20the%20Americas">European colonization</a> of Maryland began with the arrival of the merchantman "<a href="The%20Ark%20%28ship%29">The Ark</a>" carrying 140 colonists at St. Clement's Island in the Potomac River on March 25, 1634. Europeans began to settle the area further north, beginning to populate the area of <a href="Baltimore%20County">Baltimore County</a>. Since Maryland was a colony, Baltimore's streets were named to show loyalty to the mother country, e.g. King, Queen, King George and Caroline streets. The original <a href="county%20seat">county seat</a>, known today as Old Baltimore, was located on <a href="Bush%20River%20%28Maryland%29">Bush River</a> within the present-day <a href="Aberdeen%20Proving%20Ground">Aberdeen Proving Ground</a>. The colonists engaged in sporadic warfare with the Susquehanna, whose numbers dwindled primarily from new infectious diseases, such as <a href="smallpox">smallpox</a>, endemic among the Europeans. In 1661 David Jones claimed the area known today as <a href="Jonestown%2C%20Baltimore">Jonestown</a> on the east bank of the <a href="Jones%20Falls">Jones Falls</a> stream.
The colonial <a href="Maryland%20General%20Assembly">General Assembly of Maryland</a> created the <a href="Port%20of%20Baltimore">Port of Baltimore</a> at old Whetstone Point (now <a href="Locust%20Point%2C%20Baltimore">Locust Point</a>) in 1706 for the <a href="Tobacco%20in%20the%20American%20Colonies">tobacco trade</a>. The Town of Baltimore, on the west side of the Jones Falls, was founded and laid out on July 30, 1729. By 1752 the town had just 27 homes, including a church and two taverns. Jonestown and Fells Point had been settled to the east. The three settlements, covering , became a commercial hub, and in 1768 were designated as the county seat.
The first printing press was introduced to the city in 1765 by <a href="Nicholas%20Hasselbach%20%28printer%29">Nicholas Hasselbach</a>, whose equipment was later used in the printing of Baltimore's first newspapers, <a href="List%20of%20newspapers%20in%20Maryland%23Defunct">"The Maryland Journal" and "The Baltimore Advertiser"</a>, first published by <a href="William%20Goddard%20%28publisher%29">William Goddard</a> in 1773.
Baltimore grew swiftly in the 18th century, its plantations producing grain and tobacco for <a href="Sugar%20plantations%20in%20the%20Caribbean">sugar-producing colonies in the Caribbean</a>. The profit from sugar encouraged the cultivation of cane in the Caribbean and the importation of food by planters there. Since Baltimore was the county seat, a courthouse was built in 1768 to serve both the city and county. Its square was a center of community meetings and discussions.
Baltimore established its <a href="Baltimore%20Public%20Markets">public market system</a> in 1763. <a href="Lexington%20Market">Lexington Market</a>, founded in 1782, is known as one of the oldest continuously operating public markets in the United States today. Lexington Market was also a center of slave trading. Enslaved Blacks were sold at numerous sites through the downtown area, with sales advertised in "The Baltimore Sun". Both tobacco and sugar cane were labor-intensive crops.
In 1774 Baltimore established the first post office system in what became the United States, and the first water company chartered in the newly independent nation (Baltimore Water Company, 1792).
Baltimore played a key part in the <a href="American%20Revolution">American Revolution</a>. City leaders such as <a href="Jonathan%20Plowman%20Jr.">Jonathan Plowman Jr.</a> led many residents to <a href="No%20taxation%20without%20representation">resist British taxes</a>, and merchants signed agreements refusing to trade with Britain. The <a href="Second%20Continental%20Congress">Second Continental Congress</a> met in the <a href="Henry%20Fite%20House">Henry Fite House</a> from December 1776 to February 1777, effectively making the city the <a href="List%20of%20capitals%20in%20the%20United%20States">capital of the United States</a> during this period.
Antebellum period.
The Town of Baltimore, Jonestown, and Fells Point were <a href="municipal%20corporation">incorporated</a> as the "City of Baltimore" in 1796–1797. The city remained a part of surrounding <a href="Baltimore%20County%2C%20Maryland">Baltimore County</a> and continued to serve as its county seat from 1768 to 1851, after which it became an <a href="Independent%20city%20%28United%20States%29">independent city</a>.
The <a href="Battle%20of%20Baltimore">Battle of Baltimore</a> against the British in 1814 inspired the U.S. national anthem, "<a href="The%20Star-Spangled%20Banner">The Star-Spangled Banner</a>", and the construction of the <a href="Battle%20Monument">Battle Monument</a> which became the city's official emblem. A distinctive local culture started to take shape, and a unique skyline peppered with churches and monuments developed. Baltimore acquired its moniker "The Monumental City" after an 1827 visit to Baltimore by President <a href="John%20Quincy%20Adams">John Quincy Adams</a>. At an evening function, Adams gave the following toast: "Baltimore: the Monumental City—May the days of her safety be as prosperous and happy, as the days of her dangers have been trying and triumphant."
Baltimore pioneered the use of <a href="gas%20lighting">gas lighting</a> in 1816, and its population grew rapidly in the following decades, with concomitant development of culture and infrastructure. The construction of the federally funded <a href="National%20Road">National Road</a> (which later became part of <a href="U.S.%20Route%2040">U.S. Route 40</a>) and the private <a href="Baltimore%20and%20Ohio%20Railroad">Baltimore and Ohio Railroad</a> (B. & O.) made Baltimore a major shipping and <a href="manufacturing">manufacturing</a> center by linking the city with major markets in the <a href="Midwestern%20United%20States">Midwest</a>. By 1820 its population had reached 60,000, and its economy had shifted from its base in tobacco plantations to <a href="sawmilling">sawmilling</a>, <a href="shipbuilding">shipbuilding</a>, and <a href="textile">textile</a> production. These industries benefited from war but successfully shifted into <a href="infrastructure">infrastructure</a> development during peacetime.
Baltimore suffered one of the worst riots of the antebellum <a href="Southern%20United%20States">South</a> in 1835, when bad investments led to the <a href="Baltimore%20bank%20riot">Baltimore bank riot</a>. It was these riots that led to the city being <a href="nickname">nickname</a>d "Mobtown". Soon after the city created the world's first dental college, the <a href="University%20of%20Maryland%20School%20of%20Dentistry">Baltimore College of Dental Surgery</a>, in 1840, and shared in the <a href="Baltimore%E2%80%93Washington%20telegraph%20line">world's first telegraph line</a>, between Baltimore and Washington, DC, in 1844.
Civil war and after.
Maryland, a <a href="slave%20state">slave state</a> with abundant popular support for <a href="secession">secession</a> in some areas, remained part of the <a href="Union%20%28American%20Civil%20War%29">Union</a> during the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>, due in part to the Union's strategic occupation of the city in 1861. The Union's capital, Washington, in the state of Maryland (geographically if not politically), was well-situated to impede Baltimore and Maryland's communication or commerce with the Confederacy. Baltimore saw the first casualties of the war on April 19, 1861, when Union Soldiers en route from the <a href="President%20Street%20Station">President Street Station</a> to <a href="Camden%20Yards">Camden Yards</a> clashed with a secessionist mob in the <a href="Baltimore%20riot%20of%201861">Pratt Street riot</a>.
In the midst of the <a href="Long%20Depression">Long Depression</a> which followed the <a href="Panic%20of%201873">Panic of 1873</a>, the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad company attempted to lower its workers' wages, leading to <a href="Baltimore%20railroad%20strike%20of%201877">strikes and riots</a> in the city and <a href="Great%20Railroad%20Strike%20of%201877">beyond</a>. Strikers clashed with the <a href="U.S.%20National%20Guard">National Guard</a>, leaving 10 dead and 25 wounded.
20th century through 1968.
On February 7, 1904, the <a href="Great%20Baltimore%20Fire">Great Baltimore Fire</a> destroyed over 1,500 buildings in 30 hours, leaving more than 70 blocks of the downtown area burned to the ground. Damages were estimated at $150 million in 1904 dollars. As the city rebuilt during the next two years, lessons learned from the fire led to improvements in firefighting equipment standards.
Baltimore lawyer Milton Dashiell advocated for an ordinance to bar African-Americans from moving into the <a href="Eutaw%20Place">Eutaw Place</a> neighborhood in northwest Baltimore. He proposed to recognize majority white residential blocks and majority black residential blocks and to prevent people from moving into housing on such blocks where they would be a minority. The Baltimore Council passed the ordinance, and it became law on December 20, 1910, with Democratic <a href="J.%20Barry%20Mahool">Mayor J. Barry Mahool</a>'s signature. The Baltimore segregation ordinance was the first of its kind in the United States. Many other southern cities followed with their own segregation ordinances, though the US Supreme Court ruled against them in "<a href="Buchanan%20v.%20Warley">Buchanan v. Warley</a>" (1917).
The city grew in area by annexing new suburbs from the surrounding counties through 1918, when the city acquired portions of Baltimore County and <a href="Anne%20Arundel%20County%2C%20Maryland">Anne Arundel County</a>. A state constitutional amendment, approved in 1948, required a special vote of the citizens in any proposed annexation area, effectively preventing any future expansion of the city's boundaries. <a href="Streetcar">Streetcar</a>s enabled the development of distant neighborhoods areas such as <a href="Edmondson%2C%20Baltimore">Edmonson Village</a> whose residents could easily commute to work downtown.
Driven by migration from the <a href="deep%20South">deep South</a> and by <a href="white%20flight">white suburbanization</a>, the relative size of the city's <a href="African%20American">black</a> population grew from 23.8% in 1950 to 46.4% in 1970. Encouraged by real estate <a href="blockbusting">blockbusting</a> techniques, recently settled white areas rapidly became all-black neighborhoods, in a rapid process which was nearly total by 1970.
1968 and after.
The <a href="Baltimore%20riot%20of%201968">Baltimore riot of 1968</a>, coinciding with <a href="King%20assassination%20riots">uprisings in other cities</a>, followed the <a href="assassination%20of%20Martin%20Luther%20King%2C%20Jr.">assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr.</a> on April 4, 1968. Public order was not restored until April 12, 1968. The Baltimore uprising cost the city an estimated $10 million (US$ million in ). A total of 11,000 Maryland National Guard and federal troops were ordered into the city. The city experienced challenges again in 1974 when teachers, <a href="Baltimore%20municipal%20strike%20of%201974">municipal workers</a>, and <a href="Baltimore%20police%20strike">police officers</a> conducted strikes.
Following the <a href="death%20of%20Freddie%20Gray">death of Freddie Gray</a> in April 2015, the city experienced <a href="2015%20Baltimore%20protests">major protests</a> and international media attention, as well as a clash between local youth and police which resulted in a <a href="state%20of%20emergency">state of emergency</a> declaration and curfew.
Baltimore has suffered from a <a href="Crime%20in%20Baltimore">high homicide rate</a> for several decades, peaking in 1993, and again in 2015. These deaths have taken a severe toll, especially within the local black community.
Development and promotion.
By the beginning of the 1970s, Baltimore's downtown area, known as the Inner Harbor, had been neglected and was occupied by a collection of abandoned warehouses. The nickname "Charm City" came from a 1975 meeting of advertisers seeking to improve the city's reputation. Efforts to redevelop the area started with the construction of the <a href="Maryland%20Science%20Center">Maryland Science Center</a>, which opened in 1976, the <a href="Baltimore%20World%20Trade%20Center">Baltimore World Trade Center</a> (1977), and the <a href="Baltimore%20Convention%20Center">Baltimore Convention Center</a> (1979). <a href="Harborplace">Harborplace</a>, an urban retail and restaurant complex, opened on the waterfront in 1980, followed by the <a href="National%20Aquarium%20in%20Baltimore">National Aquarium</a>, Maryland's largest tourist destination, and the <a href="Baltimore%20Museum%20of%20Industry">Baltimore Museum of Industry</a> in 1981. In 1995, the city opened the <a href="American%20Visionary%20Art%20Museum">American Visionary Art Museum</a> on Federal Hill. During the <a href="HIV/AIDS%20in%20the%20United%20States">epidemic of HIV/AIDS in the United States</a>, <a href="Baltimore%20City%20Health%20Department">Baltimore City Health Department</a> official Robert Mehl persuaded the city's mayor to form a committee to address food problems; the Baltimore-based charity <a href="Moveable%20Feast%20%28organization%29">Moveable Feast</a> grew out of this initiative in 1990. By 2010, the organization's region of service had expanded from merely Baltimore to include all of the <a href="Eastern%20Shore%20of%20Maryland">Eastern Shore of Maryland</a>. In 1992, the <a href="Baltimore%20Orioles">Baltimore Orioles</a> <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">baseball team</a> moved from <a href="Memorial%20Stadium%20%28Baltimore%29">Memorial Stadium</a> to <a href="Oriole%20Park%20at%20Camden%20Yards">Oriole Park at Camden Yards</a>, located downtown near the harbor. <a href="Pope%20John%20Paul%20II">Pope John Paul II</a> held an open-air mass at Camden Yards during his papal visit to the United States in October 1995. Three years later the <a href="Baltimore%20Ravens">Baltimore Ravens</a> <a href="National%20Football%20League">football team</a> moved into <a href="M%26amp%3BT%20Bank%20Stadium">M&T Bank Stadium</a> next to Camden Yards.
Baltimore has seen the reopening of the <a href="Hippodrome%20Theatre%20%28Baltimore%29">Hippodrome Theatre</a> in 2004, the opening of the <a href="Reginald%20F.%20Lewis%20Museum%20of%20Maryland%20African%20American%20History%20%26amp%3B%20Culture">Reginald F. Lewis Museum of Maryland African American History & Culture</a> in 2005, and the establishment of the <a href="National%20Slavic%20Museum">National Slavic Museum</a> in 2012. On April 12, 2012, Johns Hopkins held a dedication ceremony to mark the completion of one of the United States' largest medical complexes – the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore – which features the Sheikh Zayed Cardiovascular and Critical Care Tower and The Charlotte R. Bloomberg Children's Center. The event, held at the entrance to the $1.1 billion 1.6 million-square-foot-facility, honored the many donors including <a href="Zayed%20bin%20Sultan%20Al%20Nahyan">Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan</a>, first president of the <a href="United%20Arab%20Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a>, and <a href="Michael%20Bloomberg">Michael Bloomberg</a>.
On September 19, 2016, the Baltimore City Council approved a $660 million bond deal for the $5.5 billion <a href="Port%20Covington">Port Covington</a> redevelopment project championed by <a href="Under%20Armour">Under Armour</a> founder <a href="Kevin%20Plank">Kevin Plank</a> and his real estate company Sagamore Development. Port Covington surpassed the Harbor Point development as the largest <a href="tax-increment%20financing">tax-increment financing</a> deal in Baltimore's history and among the largest urban redevelopment projects in the country. The waterfront development that includes the new headquarters for Under Armour, as well as shops, housing, offices, and manufacturing spaces is projected to create 26,500 permanent jobs with a $4.3 billion annual economic impact. <a href="Goldman%20Sachs">Goldman Sachs</a> invested $233 million into the redevelopment project.
Geography.
Baltimore is in north-central Maryland on the <a href="Patapsco%20River">Patapsco River</a> close to where it empties into the <a href="Chesapeake%20Bay">Chesapeake Bay</a>. The city is also located on the <a href="fall%20line">fall line</a> between the <a href="Piedmont%20%28United%20States%29">Piedmont</a> Plateau and the <a href="Atlantic%20coastal%20plain">Atlantic coastal plain</a>, which divides Baltimore into "lower city" and "upper city". The city's elevation ranges from sea level at the harbor to in the northwest corner near <a href="Pimlico%2C%20Baltimore">Pimlico</a>.
According to the 2010 Census, the city has a total area of , of which is land and is water. The total area is 12.1 percent water.
Baltimore is almost surrounded by Baltimore County, but is <a href="Independent%20city%20%28United%20States%29">politically independent</a> of it. It is bordered by <a href="Anne%20Arundel%20County">Anne Arundel County</a> to the south.
Cityscape.
Architecture.
Baltimore exhibits examples from each period of architecture over more than two centuries, and work from architects such as <a href="Benjamin%20Henry%20Latrobe">Benjamin Latrobe</a>, <a href="George%20A.%20Frederick">George A. Frederick</a>, <a href="John%20Russell%20Pope">John Russell Pope</a>, <a href="Mies%20van%20der%20Rohe">Mies van der Rohe</a> and <a href="I.%20M.%20Pei">I. M. Pei</a>.
The city is rich in architecturally significant buildings in a variety of styles. The <a href="Basilica%20of%20the%20National%20Shrine%20of%20the%20Assumption%20of%20the%20Blessed%20Virgin%20Mary">Baltimore Basilica</a> (1806–1821) is a neoclassical design by Benjamin Latrobe, and also the oldest Catholic cathedral in the United States. In 1813 Robert Cary Long, Sr., built for <a href="Rembrandt%20Peale">Rembrandt Peale</a> the first substantial structure in the United States designed expressly as a museum. Restored is now the Municipal Museum of Baltimore, or popularly the <a href="Peale%20Museum">Peale Museum</a>.
The <a href="McKim%27s%20School">McKim Free School</a> was founded and endowed by John McKim. However, the building was erected by his son <a href="Isaac%20McKim">Isaac</a> in 1822 after a design by William Howard and William Small. It reflects the popular interest in <a href="ancient%20Greece">Greece</a> when the nation was securing its independence and a scholarly interest in recently published drawings of Athenian antiquities.
The <a href="Phoenix%20Shot%20Tower">Phoenix Shot Tower</a> (1828), at tall, was the tallest building in the United States until the time of the Civil War, and is one of few remaining structures of its kind. It was constructed without the use of exterior scaffolding. The Sun Iron Building, designed by R.C. Hatfield in 1851, was the city's first iron-front building and was a model for a whole generation of downtown buildings. <a href="Brown%20Memorial%20Presbyterian%20Church">Brown Memorial Presbyterian Church</a>, built in 1870 in memory of financier <a href="George%20Brown%20%28financier%29">George Brown</a>, has <a href="stained%20glass">stained glass</a> windows by <a href="Louis%20Comfort%20Tiffany">Louis Comfort Tiffany</a> and has been called "one of the most significant buildings in this city, a treasure of art and architecture" by "<a href="Baltimore%20%28magazine%29">Baltimore</a>" magazine.
The 1845 <a href="Greek%20Revival%20architecture">Greek Revival</a>-style <a href="Lloyd%20Street%20Synagogue">Lloyd Street Synagogue</a> is one of the <a href="oldest%20synagogues%20in%20the%20United%20States">oldest synagogues in the United States</a>. The <a href="Johns%20Hopkins%20Hospital">Johns Hopkins Hospital</a>, designed by <a href="John%20Shaw%20Billings">Lt. Col. John S. Billings</a> in 1876, was a considerable achievement for its day in functional arrangement and fireproofing.
I.M. Pei's <a href="Baltimore%20World%20Trade%20Center">World Trade Center</a> (1977) is the tallest equilateral pentagonal building in the world at tall.
The <a href="Inner%20Harbor%20East">Harbor East</a> area has seen the addition of two new towers which have completed construction: a 24-floor tower that is the new world headquarters of <a href="Legg%20Mason">Legg Mason</a>, and a 21-floor <a href="Four%20Seasons%20Hotel">Four Seasons Hotel</a> complex.
The streets of Baltimore are organized in a <a href="Grid%20plan">grid pattern</a>, lined with tens of thousands of brick and <a href="formstone">formstone</a>-faced <a href="Terraced%20house">rowhouses</a>. In "The Baltimore Rowhouse", Mary Ellen Hayward and <a href="Charles%20Belfoure">Charles Belfoure</a> considered the rowhouse as the architectural form defining Baltimore as "perhaps no other American city". In the mid-1790s, developers began building entire neighborhoods of the British-style rowhouses, which became the dominant house type of the city early in the 19th century.
Formstone facings, now a common feature on Baltimore rowhouses, were an addition patented in 1937 by Albert Knight. <a href="John%20Waters%20%28director%20born%201946%29">John Waters</a> characterized formstone as "the polyester of brick" in a 30-minute documentary film, "Little Castles: A Formstone Phenomenon".
<a href="Oriole%20Park%20at%20Camden%20Yards">Oriole Park at Camden Yards</a> is a Major League Baseball park, opened in 1992, which was built as a <a href="retro%20style">retro style</a> <a href="baseball%20park">baseball park</a>. Camden Yards, along with the National Aquarium, have helped revive the Inner Harbor from what once was an <a href="industrial%20district">industrial district</a> full of dilapidated warehouses into a bustling commercial district full of bars, restaurants and retail establishments. Today, the Inner Harbor has some of the most desirable real estate in the Mid-Atlantic.
After an international competition, the <a href="University%20of%20Baltimore%20School%20of%20Law">University of Baltimore School of Law</a> awarded the German firm <a href="Behnisch%20Architekten">Behnisch Architekten</a> 1st prize for its design, which was selected for the school's new home. After the building's opening in 2013, the design won additional honors including an ENR National "Best of the Best" Award.
Baltimore's newly rehabilitated <a href="Everyman%20Theatre%2C%20Baltimore">Everyman Theatre</a> was honored by the Baltimore Heritage at the 2013 Preservation Awards Celebration in 2013. Everyman Theatre will receive an Adaptive Reuse and Compatible Design Award as part of Baltimore Heritage's 2013 historic preservation awards ceremony. Baltimore Heritage is Baltimore's nonprofit historic and architectural preservation organization, which works to preserve and promote Baltimore's historic buildings and neighborhoods.
Neighborhoods.
Baltimore is officially divided into nine geographical regions: North, Northeast, East, Southeast, South, Southwest, West, Northwest, and Central, with each district patrolled by a respective <a href="Baltimore%20Police%20Department">Baltimore Police Department</a>. <a href="Interstate%2083">Interstate 83</a> and <a href="Charles%20Street%20%28Baltimore%29">Charles Street</a> down to <a href="Maryland%20Route%202">Hanover Street</a> and <a href="Ritchie%20Highway">Ritchie Highway</a> serve as the east–west dividing line and <a href="Maryland%20Route%20150">Eastern Avenue</a> to <a href="U.S.%20Route%2040%20in%20Maryland">Route 40</a> as the north–south dividing line; however, <a href="Baltimore%20Street">Baltimore Street</a> is north–south dividing line for the <a href="U.S.%20Postal%20Service">U.S. Postal Service</a>.
Central Baltimore.
Central Baltimore, originally called the Middle District, stretches north of the Inner Harbor up to the edge of <a href="Druid%20Hill%20Park">Druid Hill Park</a>. Downtown Baltimore has mainly served as a commercial district with limited residential opportunities; however, between 2000 and 2010, the downtown population grew 130 percent as old commercial properties have been replaced by residential property. Still the city's main commercial area and business district, it includes Baltimore's sports complexes: <a href="Oriole%20Park%20at%20Camden%20Yards">Oriole Park at Camden Yards</a>, <a href="M%26amp%3BT%20Bank%20Stadium">M&T Bank Stadium</a>, and the <a href="Royal%20Farms%20Arena">Royal Farms Arena</a>; and the shops and attractions in the Inner Harbor: <a href="Harborplace">Harborplace</a>, the <a href="Baltimore%20Convention%20Center">Baltimore Convention Center</a>, the <a href="National%20Aquarium%20in%20Baltimore">National Aquarium</a>, <a href="Maryland%20Science%20Center">Maryland Science Center</a>, <a href="Pier%20Six%20Pavilion">Pier Six Pavilion</a>, and <a href="Power%20Plant%20Live">Power Plant Live</a>.
The <a href="University%20of%20Maryland%2C%20Baltimore">University of Maryland, Baltimore</a>, the <a href="University%20of%20Maryland%20Medical%20Center">University of Maryland Medical Center</a>, and <a href="Lexington%20Market">Lexington Market</a> are also in the central district, as well as the <a href="Hippodrome">Hippodrome</a> and many nightclubs, bars, restaurants, shopping centers and various other attractions. The northern portion of Central Baltimore, between downtown and the Druid Hill Park, is home to many of the city's cultural opportunities. <a href="Maryland%20Institute%20College%20of%20Art">Maryland Institute College of Art</a>, the <a href="Peabody%20Institute">Peabody Institute</a> (music conservatory), <a href="George%20Peabody%20Library">George Peabody Library</a>, <a href="Enoch%20Pratt%20Free%20Library">Enoch Pratt Free Library</a> – Central Library, the <a href="Lyric%20Opera%20House">Lyric Opera House</a>, the <a href="Joseph%20Meyerhoff%20Symphony%20Hall">Joseph Meyerhoff Symphony Hall</a>, the <a href="Walters%20Art%20Museum">Walters Art Museum</a>, the <a href="Maryland%20Center%20for%20History%20and%20Culture">Maryland Center for History and Culture</a> and its <a href="Enoch%20Pratt">Enoch Pratt</a> Mansion, and several galleries are located in this region.
North Baltimore.
Several historic and notable neighborhoods are in this district: <a href="Govans%2C%20Baltimore">Govans</a> (1755), <a href="Roland%20Park%2C%20Baltimore">Roland Park</a> (1891), <a href="Guilford%2C%20Baltimore">Guilford</a> (1913), <a href="Homeland%2C%20Baltimore">Homeland</a> (1924), <a href="Hampden%2C%20Baltimore">Hampden</a>, <a href="Woodberry%2C%20Baltimore">Woodberry</a>, <a href="Old%20Goucher%20College%20Buildings">Old Goucher</a> (the original campus of <a href="Goucher%20College">Goucher College</a>), and <a href="Jones%20Falls">Jones Falls</a>. Along the <a href="Maryland%20Route%2045">York Road</a> corridor going north are the large neighborhoods of <a href="Charles%20Village">Charles Village</a>, <a href="Waverly%2C%20Baltimore">Waverly</a>, and <a href="Mount%20Washington%2C%20Baltimore">Mount Washington</a>. The <a href="Station%20North%20Arts%20and%20Entertainment%20District">Station North Arts and Entertainment District</a> is also located in North Baltimore.
South Baltimore.
South Baltimore, a mixed industrial and residential area, consists of the "Old South Baltimore" peninsula below the Inner Harbor and east of the old <a href="B%26amp%3BO%20Railroad">B&O Railroad</a>'s Camden line tracks and <a href="Russell%20Street%20%28Baltimore%29">Russell Street</a> downtown. It is a culturally, ethnically, and socioeconomically diverse waterfront area with neighborhoods such as <a href="Locust%20Point%2C%20Baltimore">Locust Point</a> and Riverside around a large park of the same name. Just south of the Inner Harbor, the historic <a href="Federal%20Hill%2C%20Baltimore">Federal Hill</a> neighborhood, is home to many working professionals, pubs and restaurants. At the end of the peninsula is historic <a href="Fort%20McHenry">Fort McHenry</a>, a National Park since the end of World War I, when the old U.S. Army Hospital surrounding the 1798 star-shaped battlements was torn down.
Across the Hanover Street Bridge are residential areas such as <a href="Cherry%20Hill%2C%20Baltimore">Cherry Hill</a>.
Northeast Baltimore.
Northeast is primarily a residential neighborhood, home to <a href="Morgan%20State%20University">Morgan State University</a>, bounded by the city line of 1919 on its northern and eastern boundaries, <a href="Sinclair%20Lane">Sinclair Lane</a>, <a href="Maryland%20Route%20151">Erdman Avenue</a>, and <a href="U.S.%20Route%2040%20in%20Maryland">Pulaski Highway</a> to the south and <a href="The%20Alameda%20%28Baltimore%29">The Alameda</a> on to the west. Also in this wedge of the city on <a href="33rd%20Street%20%28Baltimore%29">33rd Street</a> is <a href="Baltimore%20City%20College">Baltimore City College</a> high school, third oldest active public secondary school in the United States, founded downtown in 1839. Across <a href="Loch%20Raven%20Boulevard">Loch Raven Boulevard</a> is the former site of the old <a href="Memorial%20Stadium%20%28Baltimore%29">Memorial Stadium</a> home of the <a href="History%20of%20the%20Indianapolis%20Colts">Baltimore Colts</a>, <a href="Baltimore%20Orioles">Baltimore Orioles</a>, and <a href="Baltimore%20Ravens">Baltimore Ravens</a>, now replaced by a <a href="YMCA">YMCA</a> athletic and housing complex. <a href="Lake%20Montebello">Lake Montebello</a> is in Northeast Baltimore.
East Baltimore.
Located below <a href="Sinclair%20Lane">Sinclair Lane</a> and <a href="Maryland%20Route%20151">Erdman Avenue</a>, above <a href="Orleans%20Street%20%28Baltimore%29">Orleans Street</a>, East Baltimore is mainly made up of residential neighborhoods. This section of East Baltimore is home to <a href="Johns%20Hopkins%20Hospital">Johns Hopkins Hospital</a>, <a href="Johns%20Hopkins%20University%20School%20of%20Medicine">Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine</a>, and <a href="Johns%20Hopkins%20Children%27s%20Center">Johns Hopkins Children's Center</a> on <a href="Broadway%20%28Baltimore%29">Broadway</a>. Notable neighborhoods include: <a href="Armistead%20Gardens">Armistead Gardens</a>, <a href="Broadway%20East">Broadway East</a>, <a href="Barclay%2C%20Baltimore">Barclay</a>, <a href="Ellwood%20Park">Ellwood Park</a>, <a href="Greenmount%2C%20Baltimore">Greenmount</a>, and <a href="McElderry%20Park">McElderry Park</a>.
This area was the on-site film location for "", "<a href="The%20Corner">The Corner</a>" and "<a href="The%20Wire">The Wire</a>".
Southeast Baltimore.
Southeast Baltimore, located below <a href="Fayette%20Street">Fayette Street</a>, bordering the Inner Harbor and the Northwest Branch of the <a href="Patapsco%20River">Patapsco River</a> to the west, the city line of 1919 on its eastern boundaries and the Patapsco River to the south, is a mixed industrial and residential area. <a href="Patterson%20Park">Patterson Park</a>, the "Best Backyard in Baltimore", as well as the <a href="Highlandtown%20Arts%20District%2C%20Baltimore%2C%20MD">Highlandtown Arts District</a>, and <a href="Johns%20Hopkins%20Bayview%20Medical%20Center">Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center</a> are located in Southeast Baltimore. The Shops at Canton Crossing opened in 2013. The <a href="Canton%2C%20Baltimore">Canton</a> neighborhood, is located along Baltimore's prime waterfront. Other historic neighborhoods include: <a href="Fell%27s%20Point%2C%20Baltimore">Fells Point</a>, <a href="Patterson%20Park%20%28neighborhood%29%2C%20Baltimore">Patterson Park</a>, <a href="Butchers%20Hill%2C%20Baltimore">Butchers Hill</a>, <a href="Highlandtown%2C%20Baltimore">Highlandtown</a>, <a href="Greektown%2C%20Baltimore">Greektown</a>, <a href="Inner%20Harbor%20East%2C%20Baltimore">Harbor East</a>, <a href="Little%20Italy%2C%20Baltimore">Little Italy</a>, and <a href="Upper%20Fell%27s%20Point">Upper Fell's Point</a>.
Northwest Baltimore.
Northwestern is bounded by the county line to the north and west, <a href="Gwynns%20Falls%20Parkway">Gwynns Falls Parkway</a> on the south and <a href="Pimlico%20Road">Pimlico Road</a> on the east, is home to <a href="Pimlico%20Race%20Course">Pimlico Race Course</a>, <a href="Sinai%20Hospital%20%28Maryland%29">Sinai Hospital</a>, and the headquarters of the <a href="NAACP">NAACP</a>. Its neighborhoods are mostly residential and are dissected by <a href="Northern%20Parkway%20%28Baltimore%29">Northern Parkway</a>. The area has been the center of <a href="History%20of%20the%20Jews%20in%20Baltimore">Baltimore's Jewish community</a> since after World War II. Notable neighborhoods include: <a href="Pimlico%2C%20Baltimore">Pimlico</a>, <a href="Mount%20Washington%2C%20Baltimore">Mount Washington</a>, and <a href="Cheswolde%2C%20Baltimore">Cheswolde</a>, and <a href="Park%20Heights">Park Heights</a>.
West Baltimore.
West Baltimore is west of downtown and the <a href="Martin%20Luther%20King%20Jr.%20Boulevard%20%28Baltimore%29">Martin Luther King, Jr. Boulevard</a> and is bounded by Gwynns Falls Parkway, <a href="Fremont%20Avenue">Fremont Avenue</a>, and <a href="Baltimore%20Street">West Baltimore Street</a>. The <a href="Old%20West%20Baltimore%20Historic%20District">Old West Baltimore Historic District</a> includes the neighborhoods of <a href="Harlem%20Park">Harlem Park</a>, <a href="Sandtown-Winchester">Sandtown-Winchester</a>, <a href="Druid%20Heights">Druid Heights</a>, <a href="Madison%20Park%2C%20Baltimore">Madison Park</a>, and <a href="Upton%2C%20Baltimore">Upton</a>. Originally a predominantly German neighborhood, by the last half of the 19th century, Old West Baltimore was home to a substantial section of the city's black population. It became the largest neighborhood for the city's black community and its cultural, political, and economic center. <a href="Coppin%20State%20University">Coppin State University</a>, <a href="Mondawmin%20Mall">Mondawmin Mall</a>, and <a href="Edmondson%2C%20Baltimore">Edmondson Village</a> are located in this district. The area's crime problems have provided subject material for television series, such as "<a href="The%20Wire">The Wire</a>". Local organizations, such as the Sandtown Habitat for Humanity and the Upton Planning Committee, have been steadily transforming parts of formerly blighted areas of West Baltimore into clean, safe communities.
Southwest Baltimore.
Southwest Baltimore is bound by the Baltimore County line to the west, West <a href="Baltimore%20Street">Baltimore Street</a> to the north, and <a href="Martin%20Luther%20King%20Jr.%20Boulevard%20%28Baltimore%29">Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard</a> and <a href="Baltimore%E2%80%93Washington%20Parkway">Russell Street/Baltimore-Washington Parkway</a> (Maryland Route 295) to the east. Notable neighborhoods in Southwest Baltimore include: <a href="Pigtown%2C%20Baltimore">Pigtown</a>, <a href="Carrollton%20Ridge%2C%20Baltimore">Carrollton Ridge</a>, <a href="Ridgely%27s%20Delight%2C%20Baltimore">Ridgely's Delight</a>, <a href="Gwynns%20Falls%20Leakin%20Park">Leakin Park</a>, <a href="Violetville%2C%20Baltimore">Violetville</a>, <a href="Lakeland%2C%20Baltimore">Lakeland</a>, and <a href="Morrell%20Park%2C%20Baltimore">Morrell Park</a>.
<a href="St.%20Agnes%20Hospital%20%28Baltimore%29">St. Agnes Hospital</a> on <a href="Maryland%20Route%20372">Wilkens</a> and <a href="Caton%20Avenue">Caton</a> avenues is located in this district with the neighboring <a href="Cardinal%20Gibbons%20School%20%28Baltimore%2C%20Maryland%29">Cardinal Gibbons High School</a>, which is the former site of <a href="Babe%20Ruth">Babe Ruth</a>'s alma mater, St. Mary's Industrial School. Also through this segment of Baltimore ran the beginnings of the historic <a href="National%20Road">National Road</a>, which was constructed beginning in 1806 along <a href="Old%20Frederick%20Road">Old Frederick Road</a> and continuing into the county on <a href="Maryland%20Route%20144">Frederick Road</a> into <a href="Ellicott%20City%2C%20Maryland">Ellicott City, Maryland</a>. Other sides in this district are: <a href="Mount%20Clare%20%28Maryland%29">Carroll Park</a>, one of the city's largest parks, the colonial Mount Clare Mansion, and <a href="U.S.%20Route%201%20in%20Maryland">Washington Boulevard</a>, which dates to pre-Revolutionary War days as the prime route out of the city to <a href="Alexandria%2C%20Virginia">Alexandria, Virginia</a>, and <a href="Georgetown%20%28Washington%2C%20D.C.%29">Georgetown</a> on the <a href="Potomac%20River">Potomac River</a>.
Adjacent communities.
The City of Baltimore is bordered by the following communities, all unincorporated <a href="census-designated%20place">census-designated place</a>s.
Climate.
Baltimore has a <a href="humid%20subtropical%20climate">humid subtropical climate</a> ("Cfa") in the <a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen climate classification</a>, with long, hot summers, cool winters, and a summer peak to annual precipitation. Baltimore is part of USDA plant <a href="hardiness%20zone">hardiness zone</a>s 7b and 8a. Summers are normally hot, with occasional late day thunderstorms. July, the hottest month, has a mean temperature of . Winters are chilly to mild but variable, with sporadic snowfall: January has a daily average of , though temperatures reach rather often, but can drop below when Arctic air masses affect the area.
Spring and autumn are warm, with spring being the wettest season in terms of the number of precipitation days. Summers are hot and humid with a daily average in July of , and the combination of heat and humidity leads to rather frequent thunderstorms. A southeasterly bay breeze off the Chesapeake often occurs on summer afternoons when hot air rises over inland areas; prevailing winds from the southwest interacting with this breeze as well as the city proper's UHI can seriously exacerbate air quality. In late summer and early autumn the track of hurricanes or their remnants may cause flooding in downtown Baltimore, despite the city being far removed from the typical coastal <a href="storm%20surge">storm surge</a> areas.
The average seasonal snowfall is , but it varies greatly depending on the winter, with some seasons seeing minimal snow while others see several major <a href="Nor%27easter">Nor'easter</a>s. Owing to lessened <a href="urban%20heat%20island">urban heat island</a> (UHI) as compared to the <a href="city%20limits">city proper</a> and distance from the moderating Chesapeake Bay, the outlying and inland parts of the Baltimore metro area are usually cooler, especially at night, than the city proper and the coastal towns. Thus, in the northern and western suburbs, winter snowfall is more significant, and some areas average more than of snow per winter. It is by no means uncommon for the rain-snow line to set up in the metro area. <a href="Freezing%20rain">Freezing rain</a> and sleet occurs a few times each winter in the area, as warm air overrides cold air at the low to mid-levels of the atmosphere. When the wind blows from the east, the cold air gets <a href="cold%20air%20damming">dammed against the mountains</a> to the west and the result is freezing rain or sleet.
Like <a href="Climate%20change%20in%20Maryland">all of Maryland</a>, Baltimore is at risk for increased impacts of <a href="Global%20warming">climate change</a>. Historically, flooding has ruined houses and almost killed people, especially in lower income majority black neighborhoods, and caused additional sewage backups, given the existing disrepair of Baltimore's water system.
Extreme temperatures range from on February 9, 1934, and <a href="Great%20Blizzard%20of%201899">February 10, 1899</a>, up to on July 22, 2011. On average, temperatures of or more occur on three days annually, or more on 43 days, and there are nine days where the high fails to reach the freezing mark.
Demographics.
Population.
In 2011, then-Mayor <a href="Stephanie%20Rawlings-Blake">Stephanie Rawlings-Blake</a> said her main goal was to increase the city's population by improving city services to reduce the number of people leaving the city and by passing legislation protecting immigrants' rights to stimulate growth. Baltimore is sometimes identified as a <a href="sanctuary%20city">sanctuary city</a>. Mayor <a href="Jack%20Young%20%28politician%29">Jack Young</a> said in 2019 that Baltimore will not assist <a href="U.S.%20Immigration%20and%20Customs%20Enforcement">ICE</a> agents with immigration raids.
Baltimore City's population has declined overall from 2010 to 2020 by about 34,830 people, representing a 5.6% drop. The official US census places the city's population at 585,708 for 2020. The year between 2018 and 2019 had the largest year-to-year population loss, and in 2020 Baltimore lost more population than any other major city in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>.
<a href="Gentrification">Gentrification</a> has increased since the 2000 census, primarily in East Baltimore, downtown, and Central Baltimore, with 14.8% of census tracts having had income growth and home values appreciation at a rate higher than the city overall. Most, but not all, gentrifying neighborhoods are predominantly white areas which have seen a turnover from lower income to higher income households. These areas represent either expansion of existing gentrified areas, or activity around the Inner Harbor, downtown, or the Johns Hopkins Homewood campus. In some neighborhoods in East Baltimore, the Hispanic population has increased along with home values and income, while both the non-Hispanic white and non-Hispanic black populations have declined, a trend which is not seen in many other American cities.
After <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>, Baltimore was the second city in the United States to reach a population of 100,000. From the 1820 through 1850 U.S. censuses, Baltimore was the second most-populous city, before being surpassed by Philadelphia in 1860. It was among the top 10 cities in population in the United States in every census up through the 1980 census, and after World War II had a population of nearly 1 million.
Characteristics.
According to the , Baltimore's population is 63.7% <a href="African%20Americans">Black</a>, 29.6% <a href="White%20Americans">White</a> (6.9% <a href="German%20Americans">German</a>, 5.8% <a href="Italian%20Americans">Italian</a>, 4% <a href="Irish%20Americans">Irish</a>, 2% <a href="Americans">American</a>, 2% <a href="Polish%20Americans">Polish</a>, 0.5% <a href="Greek%20Americans">Greek</a>) 2.3% <a href="Asian%20Americans">Asian</a> (0.54% <a href="Korean%20Americans">Korean</a>, 0.46% <a href="Indian%20Americans">Indian</a>, 0.37% <a href="Chinese%20Americans">Chinese</a>, 0.36% <a href="Filipino%20Americans">Filipino</a>, 0.21% <a href="Nepali%20American">Nepali</a>, 0.16% <a href="Pakistani%20Americans">Pakistani</a>), and 0.4% <a href="Native%20Americans%20in%20the%20United%20States">Native American and Alaska Native.</a> Across races, 4.2% of the population are of <a href="History%20of%20the%20Hispanics%20and%20Latinos%20in%20Baltimore">Hispanic, Latino, or Spanish origin</a> (1.63% <a href="Salvadoran%20Americans">Salvadoran</a>, 1.21% <a href="Mexican%20Americans">Mexican</a>, 0.63% <a href="Puerto%20Rican-American">Puerto Rican</a>, 0.6% <a href="Honduran%20Americans">Honduran</a>). Females made up 53.4% of the population. The median age was 35 years old, with 22.4% under 18 years old, 65.8% from 18 to 64 years old, and 11.8% 65 or older.
Baltimore also has a large <a href="Caribbean%20American">Caribbean American</a> population, with the largest groups being <a href="Jamaican%20Americans">Jamaicans</a> and <a href="Trinidadian%20and%20Tobagonian%20Americans">Trinidadians</a>. Baltimore's Jamaican community is largely centered in the <a href="Park%20Heights%2C%20Baltimore">Park Heights</a> neighborhood, but generations of immigrants have also lived in Southeast Baltimore.
In 2005, approximately 30,778 people (6.5%) identified as <a href="LGBT">gay, lesbian, or bisexual</a>. In 2012, <a href="same-sex%20marriage%20in%20Maryland">same-sex marriage in Maryland</a> was legalized, going into effect January 1, 2013.
Income and housing.
In 2009, the median household income was $42,241 and the median income per capita was $25,707, compared to the national median income of $53,889 per household and $28,930 per capita. In Baltimore, 23.7% of the population lived below the poverty line, compared to 13.5% nationwide.
Housing in Baltimore is relatively inexpensive for large, coastal cities of its size. The median sale price for homes in Baltimore in 2012 was $95,000. Despite the housing collapse, and along with the national trends, Baltimore residents still face slowly increasing rent (up 3% in the summer of 2010).
The <a href="Homelessness">homeless</a> population in Baltimore is steadily increasing; it exceeded 4,000 people in 2011. The increase in the number of young homeless people was particularly severe.
Life expectancy.
As of 2015, life expectancy in Baltimore was 74 to 75 years, compared to the U.S. average of 78 to 80. Fourteen neighborhoods had lower life expectancies than <a href="North%20Korea">North Korea</a>. The life expectancy in Downtown/Seton Hill was comparable to that of <a href="Yemen">Yemen</a>.
Religion.
According to Pew Research Center, 25% of adults in Baltimore report affiliating with no religion. 50% of the adult population of Baltimore are <a href="Protestants">Protestants</a>. Following Protestantism, <a href="Catholicism">Catholicism</a> is the second largest religious affiliation, comprising 15% percent of the population, followed by <a href="Judaism">Judaism</a> (3%) and <a href="Islam">Islam</a> (2%). Around 1% identify with other <a href="Christian%20denominations">Christian denominations</a>.
Languages.
, 91% (526,705) of Baltimore residents five years old and older spoke only English at home. Close to 4% (21,661) spoke Spanish. Other languages, such as <a href="Languages%20of%20Africa">African languages</a>, French, and Chinese are spoken by less than 1% of the population.
Crime.
Crime in Baltimore, generally concentrated in areas high in poverty, has been extreme for many years. Overall reported crime has dropped by 60% from the mid 1990s to the mid 2010s, but homicide rates remain high and exceed the national average. The worst years for crime in Baltimore overall were from 1993 to 1996; with 96,243 crimes reported in 1995. Baltimore's 344 homicides in 2015 represented the highest homicide rate in the city's recorded history—52.5 per 100,000 people, surpassing the record set in 1993—and the second-highest for U.S. cities behind <a href="St.%20Louis">St. Louis</a> and ahead of <a href="Detroit">Detroit</a>. To put that in perspective, New York City, a city with a 2015 population of 8,491,079, recorded a total of 339 homicides in 2015. Baltimore had a 2015 population of 621,849; which means that in 2015 Baltimore had a homicide rate 14 times higher than New York City's. Of Baltimore's 344 homicides in 2015, 321 (93.3%) of the victims were African-American. <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>, which saw 762 homicides in 2016 compared to Baltimore's 318, still had a homicide rate (27.2) that was half of Baltimore's because Chicago has a population four times greater than Baltimore's. As of 2018, the murder rate in Baltimore was higher than that of <a href="El%20Salvador">El Salvador</a>, <a href="Guatemala">Guatemala</a>, or <a href="Honduras">Honduras</a>. Drug use and deaths by drug use (particularly drugs used intravenously, such as heroin) are a related problem which has crippled Baltimore for decades. Among cities greater than 400,000, Baltimore ranked 2nd in its opiate drug death rate in the United States behind <a href="Dayton%2C%20Ohio">Dayton, Ohio</a>. The <a href="Drug%20Enforcement%20Administration">DEA</a> reported that 10% of Baltimore's population – about 64,000 people – are addicted to heroin.
In 2011, Baltimore police reported 196 homicides, the lowest number in the city since 197 homicides in 1978 and far lower than the peak homicide count of 353 slayings in 1993. City leaders at the time credited a sustained focus on repeat violent offenders and increased community engagement for the continued drop, reflecting a nationwide decline in crime.
On August 8, 2014, Baltimore's new youth <a href="curfew">curfew</a> law went into effect. It prohibits unaccompanied children under age 14 from being on the streets after 9 p.m. and those aged 14–16 from being out after 10 p.m. during the week and 11 p.m. on weekends and during the summer. The goal is to keep children out of dangerous places and reduce crime.
Crime in Baltimore reached another peak in 2015 when the year's tally of 344 homicides was second only to the record 353 in 1993, when Baltimore had about 100,000 more residents. The killings in 2015 were on pace with recent years in the early months of 2015 but skyrocketed after the <a href="Baltimore%20Uprising">unrest and rioting of late April</a>. In five of the next eight months, killings topped 30–40 per month. Nearly 90 percent of 2015's homicides resulted from shootings, renewing calls for new gun laws. In 2016, according to annual crime statistics released by the Baltimore Police Department, there were 318 murders in the city. This total marked a 7.56 percent decline in homicides from 2015.
In an interview with "<a href="The%20Guardian">The Guardian</a>", on November 2, 2017, <a href="David%20Simon">David Simon</a>, himself a former police reporter for "<a href="The%20Baltimore%20Sun">The Baltimore Sun</a>", ascribed the most recent surge in murders to the high-profile decision by Baltimore state's attorney, <a href="Marilyn%20Mosby">Marilyn Mosby</a>, to charge six city police officers following the <a href="death%20of%20Freddie%20Gray">death of Freddie Gray</a> after he fell into a coma while in police custody in April 2015. "What Mosby basically did was send a message to the Baltimore police department: 'I'm going to put you in jail for making a bad arrest.' So officers figured it out: 'I can go to jail for making the wrong arrest, so I'm not getting out of my car to clear a corner,' and that's exactly what happened post-Freddie Gray." In Baltimore, "arrest numbers have plummeted from more than 40,000 in 2014, the year before Gray's death and the subsequent charges against the officers, to about 18,000 [as of November 2017]. This happened even as homicides soared from 211 in 2014 to 344 in 2015 – an increase of 63%."
Economy.
Once a predominantly industrial town, with an economic base focused on steel processing, shipping, auto manufacturing (General Motors <a href="Baltimore%20Assembly">Baltimore Assembly</a>), and transportation, the city experienced <a href="deindustrialization">deindustrialization</a> which cost residents tens of thousands of low-skill, high-wage jobs. The city now relies on a low-wage <a href="service%20economy">service economy</a>, which accounts for 31% of jobs in the city.
Around the turn of the 20th century, Baltimore was the leading US manufacturer of <a href="rye%20whiskey">rye whiskey</a> and <a href="straw%20hat">straw hat</a>s. It also led in refining of crude oil, brought to the city by pipeline from Pennsylvania.
 the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics calculates Baltimore's unemployment rate at 5.8% while one quarter of Baltimore residents (and 37% of Baltimore children) live in poverty. The 2012 closure of a major steel plant at Sparrows Point is expected to have a further impact on employment and the local economy. The Census Bureau reported in 2013 that 207,000 workers commute into Baltimore city each day. <a href="Downtown%20Baltimore">Downtown Baltimore</a> is the primary economic asset within Baltimore City and the region with 29.1 million square feet of office space. The tech sector is rapidly growing as the Baltimore metro ranks 8th in the CBRE Tech Talent Report among 50 U.S. metro areas for high growth rate and number of tech professionals. "Forbes" ranked Baltimore fourth among America's "new tech hot spots".
The city is home to the <a href="Johns%20Hopkins%20Hospital">Johns Hopkins Hospital</a>. Other large include <a href="Under%20Armour">Under Armour</a>, <a href="BRT%20Laboratories">BRT Laboratories</a>, <a href="Cordish%20Company">Cordish Company</a>, <a href="Legg%20Mason">Legg Mason</a>, <a href="McCormick%20%26amp%3B%20Company">McCormick & Company</a>, <a href="T.%20Rowe%20Price">T. Rowe Price</a>, and <a href="Royal%20Farms">Royal Farms</a>. A <a href="sugar%20refinery">sugar refinery</a> owned by <a href="American%20Sugar%20Refining">American Sugar Refining</a> is one of Baltimore's cultural icons. Nonprofits based in Baltimore include <a href="Lutheran%20Services%20in%20America">Lutheran Services in America</a> and <a href="Catholic%20Relief%20Services">Catholic Relief Services</a>.
Almost a quarter of the jobs in the Baltimore region were in science, technology, engineering and math as of mid 2013, in part attributed to the city's extensive undergraduate and graduate schools; maintenance and repair experts were included in this count.
Port.
The center of international commerce for the region is the <a href="Baltimore%20World%20Trade%20Center">World Trade Center Baltimore</a>. It houses the Maryland Port Administration and U.S. headquarters for major shipping lines. Baltimore is ranked 9th for total dollar value of cargo and 13th for cargo tonnage for all U.S. ports. In 2014, total cargo moving through the port totaled 29.5 million tons, down from 30.3 million tons in 2013. The value of cargo traveling through the port in 2014 came to $52.5 billion, down from $52.6 billion in 2013. The <a href="Port%20of%20Baltimore">Port of Baltimore</a> generates $3 billion in annual wages and salary, as well as supporting 14,630 direct jobs and 108,000 jobs connected to port work. In 2014, the port also generated more than $300 million in taxes. It serves over 50 ocean carriers making nearly 1,800 annual visits. Among all U.S. ports, Baltimore is first in handling automobiles, light trucks, farm and construction machinery; and imported forest products, aluminum, and sugar. The port is second in coal exports. The Port of Baltimore's cruise industry, which offers year-round trips on several lines supports over 500 jobs and brings in over $90 million to Maryland's economy annually. Growth at the port continues with the Maryland Port Administration plans to turn the southern tip of the former steel mill into a marine terminal, primarily for car and truck shipments, but also for anticipated new business coming to Baltimore after the completion of the <a href="Panama%20Canal%20expansion%20project">Panama Canal expansion project</a>.
Tourism.
Baltimore's history and attractions have allowed the city to become a popular tourist destination on the East Coast. In 2014, the city hosted 24.5 million visitors, who spent $5.2 billion. The Baltimore Visitor Center, which is operated by <a href="Visit%20Baltimore">Visit Baltimore</a>, is located on Light Street in the Inner Harbor. Much of the city's tourism centers around the Inner Harbor, with the <a href="National%20Aquarium%20in%20Baltimore">National Aquarium</a> being Maryland's top tourist destination. Baltimore Harbor's restoration has made it "a city of boats", with several historic ships and other attractions on display and open for the public to visit. The <a href="USS%20Constellation%20%281854%29">USS "Constellation"</a>, the last Civil War-era vessel afloat, is docked at the head of the Inner Harbor; the <a href="USS%20Torsk%20%28SS-423%29">USS "Torsk"</a>, a submarine that holds the Navy's record for dives (more than 10,000); and the Coast Guard cutter "<a href="WHEC-37">WHEC-37</a>", the last surviving U.S. warship that was in <a href="Pearl%20Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a> during the <a href="attack%20on%20Pearl%20Harbor">Japanese attack</a> on December 7, 1941, and which engaged Japanese Zero aircraft during the battle.
Also docked is the <a href="Lightvessel">lightship</a> "Chesapeake", which for decades marked the entrance to Chesapeake Bay; and the Seven Foot Knoll Lighthouse, the oldest surviving <a href="screw-pile%20lighthouse">screw-pile lighthouse</a> on Chesapeake Bay, which once marked the mouth of the Patapsco River and the entrance to Baltimore. All of these attractions are owned and maintained by the <a href="Historic%20Ships%20in%20Baltimore">Historic Ships in Baltimore</a> organization. The Inner Harbor is also the home port of "<a href="Pride%20of%20Baltimore%20II">Pride of Baltimore II</a>", the state of Maryland's "goodwill ambassador" ship, a reconstruction of a famous <a href="Baltimore%20Clipper">Baltimore Clipper</a> ship.
Other tourist destinations include sporting venues such as <a href="Oriole%20Park%20at%20Camden%20Yards">Oriole Park at Camden Yards</a>, <a href="M%26amp%3BT%20Bank%20Stadium">M&T Bank Stadium</a>, and <a href="Pimlico%20Race%20Course">Pimlico Race Course</a>, <a href="Fort%20McHenry">Fort McHenry</a>, the <a href="Mount%20Vernon%2C%20Baltimore">Mount Vernon</a>, <a href="Federal%20Hill%2C%20Baltimore">Federal Hill</a>, and <a href="Fells%20Point">Fells Point</a> neighborhoods, <a href="Lexington%20Market">Lexington Market</a>, <a href="Horseshoe%20Casino%20Baltimore">Horseshoe Casino</a>, and museums such as the <a href="Walters%20Art%20Museum">Walters Art Museum</a>, the <a href="Baltimore%20Museum%20of%20Industry">Baltimore Museum of Industry</a>, the <a href="Babe%20Ruth">Babe Ruth</a> Birthplace and Museum, the <a href="Maryland%20Science%20Center">Maryland Science Center</a>, and the <a href="B%26amp%3BO%20Railroad%20Museum">B&O Railroad Museum</a>.
Culture.
Historically a working-class port town, Baltimore has sometimes been dubbed a "city of neighborhoods", with 72 designated historic districts traditionally occupied by distinct ethnic groups. Most notable today are three downtown areas along the port: the Inner Harbor, frequented by tourists due to its hotels, shops, and museums; Fells Point, once a favorite entertainment spot for sailors but now refurbished and gentrified (and featured in the movie "<a href="Sleepless%20in%20Seattle">Sleepless in Seattle</a>"); and <a href="Little%20Italy%2C%20Baltimore">Little Italy</a>, located between the other two, where Baltimore's Italian-American community is based – and where U.S. House Speaker <a href="Nancy%20Pelosi">Nancy Pelosi</a> grew up. Further inland, <a href="Mount%20Vernon%2C%20Baltimore">Mount Vernon</a> is the traditional center of cultural and artistic life of the city; it is home to a distinctive <a href="Washington%20Monument%20%28Baltimore%29">Washington Monument</a>, set atop a hill in a 19th-century urban square, that predates the more well-known monument in Washington, D.C. by several decades. Baltimore also has a significant <a href="History%20of%20the%20Germans%20in%20Baltimore">German American</a> population, and was the second largest port of immigration to the United States, behind <a href="Ellis%20Island">Ellis Island</a> in New York and New Jersey. Between 1820 and 1989, almost 2 million who were German, <a href="History%20of%20the%20Poles%20in%20Baltimore">Polish</a>, English, Irish, <a href="History%20of%20the%20Russians%20in%20Baltimore">Russian</a>, <a href="History%20of%20the%20Lithuanians%20in%20Baltimore">Lithuanian</a>, <a href="History%20of%20the%20French%20in%20Baltimore">French</a>, <a href="History%20of%20the%20Ukrainians%20in%20Baltimore">Ukrainian</a>, <a href="History%20of%20the%20Czechs%20in%20Baltimore">Czech</a>, <a href="History%20of%20the%20Greeks%20in%20Baltimore">Greek</a> and <a href="History%20of%20the%20Italians%20in%20Baltimore">Italian</a> came to Baltimore, most between the years 1861 to 1930. By 1913, when Baltimore was averaging forty thousand immigrants per year, World War I closed off the flow of immigrants. By 1970, Baltimore's heyday as an immigration center was a distant memory. There also was a <a href="Chinatown%2C%20Baltimore">Chinatown</a> dating back to at least the 1880s which consisted of no more than 400 Chinese residents. A local Chinese-American association remains based there, but only one Chinese restaurant as of 2009.
Baltimore has quite a history when it comes to making beer, an art that thrived in Baltimore from the 1800s to the 1950s with over 100 old breweries in the city's past. The best remaining example of that history is the old <a href="American%20Brewery%20%28building%29">American Brewery Building</a> on North Gay Street and the <a href="National%20Brewing%20Company">National Brewing Company</a> building in the <a href="Brewers%20Hill%2C%20Baltimore">Brewer's Hill</a> neighborhood. In the 1940s the National Brewing Company introduced the nation's first six-pack. National's two most prominent brands, were <a href="National%20Bohemian">National Bohemian</a> Beer colloquially "Natty Boh" and <a href="Colt%2045%20%28malt%20liquor%29">Colt 45</a>. Listed on the <a href="Pabst%20Brewing%20Company">Pabst</a> website as a "Fun Fact", Colt 45 was named after running back <a href="Jerry%20Hill%20%28American%20football%29">#45 Jerry Hill</a> of the 1963 <a href="Indianapolis%20Colts%23The%20NFL%20Baltimore%20Colts">Baltimore Colts</a> and not the <a href=".45%20Colt">.45 caliber handgun ammunition round</a>. Both brands are still made today, albeit outside of Maryland, and served all around the Baltimore area at bars, as well as <a href="Baltimore%20Orioles">Orioles</a> and <a href="Baltimore%20Ravens">Ravens</a> games. The Natty Boh logo appears on all cans, bottles, and packaging; and merchandise featuring him can still easily be found in shops in Maryland, including several in <a href="Fells%20Point">Fells Point</a>.
Each year the <a href="Artscape%20%28festival%29">Artscape</a> takes place in the city in the <a href="Bolton%20Hill%2C%20Baltimore">Bolton Hill</a> neighborhood, due to its proximity to Maryland Institute College of Art. Artscape styles itself as the "largest free arts festival in America". Each May, the <a href="Maryland%20Film%20Festival">Maryland Film Festival</a> takes place in Baltimore, using all five screens of the historic <a href="Charles%20Theatre">Charles Theatre</a> as its anchor venue. Many movies and television shows have been filmed in Baltimore. "" was set and filmed in Baltimore, as well as "<a href="The%20Wire">The Wire</a>." "<a href="House%20of%20Cards%20%28U.S.%20TV%20series%29">House of Cards</a>" and "<a href="Veep">Veep</a>" are set in Washington, D.C. but filmed in Baltimore.
Baltimore has cultural museums in many areas of study. <a href="Baltimore%20Museum%20of%20Art">The Baltimore Museum of Art</a>, and the <a href="Walters%20Art%20Museum">Walters Art Museum</a> are internationally renowned for its collection of art. The Baltimore Museum of Art has the largest holding of works by <a href="Henri%20Matisse">Henri Matisse</a> in the world. The <a href="American%20Visionary%20Art%20Museum">American Visionary Art Museum</a> has been designated by <a href="United%20States%20Congress">Congress</a> as America's national museum for <a href="visionary%20art">visionary art</a>. The <a href="National%20Great%20Blacks%20In%20Wax%20Museum">National Great Blacks In Wax Museum</a> is the first African American wax museum in the country, featuring more than 150 life-size and lifelike wax figures.
Cuisine.
Baltimore is known for its Maryland <a href="Callinectes%20sapidus">blue crabs</a>, crab cake, <a href="Old%20Bay%20Seasoning">Old Bay Seasoning</a>, pit beef, and the "chicken box". The city has many restaurants in or around the Inner Harbor. The most known and acclaimed are the Charleston, Woodberry Kitchen, and the <a href="Duff%20Goldman">Charm City Cakes</a> bakery featured on the Food Network's "<a href="Ace%20of%20Cakes">Ace of Cakes</a>". The <a href="Little%20Italy%2C%20Baltimore">Little Italy</a> neighborhood's biggest draw is the food. Fells Point also is a foodie neighborhood for tourists and locals and is where the oldest continuously running tavern in the country, "The Horse You Came in on Saloon", is located. Many of the city's upscale restaurants can be found in Harbor East. Five public markets are located across the city. The <a href="Baltimore%20Public%20Markets">Baltimore Public Market System</a> is the oldest continuously operating public market system in the United States. <a href="Lexington%20Market">Lexington Market</a> is one of the longest-running markets in the world and longest running in the country, having been around since 1782. The market continues to stand at its original site. Baltimore is the last place in America where one can still find <a href="arabber">arabber</a>s, vendors who sell fresh fruits and vegetables from a horse-drawn cart that goes up and down neighborhood streets. Food- and drink-rating site <a href="Zagat">Zagat</a> ranked Baltimore second in a list of the 17 best food cities in the country in 2015.
Local dialect.
Baltimore city, along with its surrounding regions, is home to a unique local dialect known as the <a href="Baltimore%20dialect">Baltimore dialect</a>. It is part of the larger <a href="Mid-Atlantic%20American%20English">Mid-Atlantic American English</a> group and is noted to be very similar to the <a href="Philadelphia%20dialect">Philadelphia dialect</a>, albeit with more southern influences.
The so-called "Bawlmerese" accent is known for its characteristic pronunciation of its long "o" vowel, in which an "eh" sound is added before the long "o" sound (/oʊ/ shifts to [ɘʊ], or even [eʊ]). It also adopts Philadelphia's pattern of the short "a" sound, such that the tensed vowel in words like "bath" or "ask" does not match the more relaxed one in "sad" or "act".
Baltimore native <a href="John%20Waters%20%28director%20born%201946%29">John Waters</a> parodies the city and its dialect extensively in his films. Most of them are filmed and/or set in Baltimore, including the 1972 cult classic "<a href="Pink%20Flamingos">Pink Flamingos</a>", as well as "<a href="Hairspray%20%281988%20film%29">Hairspray</a>" and its <a href="Hairspray%20%28musical%29">Broadway musical remake</a>.
Performing arts.
Baltimore has three state-designated arts and entertainment (A & E) districts. The <a href="Station%20North%20Arts%20and%20Entertainment%20District">Station North Arts and Entertainment District</a>, <a href="Highlandtown%20Arts%20District%2C%20Baltimore%2C%20MD">Highlandtown Arts District</a>, and the Bromo Arts & Entertainment District. The Baltimore Office of Promotion & The Arts, a non-profit organization, produces events and arts programs as well as manages several facilities. It is the official Baltimore City Arts Council. BOPA coordinates Baltimore's major events including New Year's Eve and July 4 celebrations at the Inner Harbor, <a href="Artscape%20%28festival%29">Artscape</a> which is America's largest free arts festival, Baltimore Book Festival, Baltimore Farmers' Market & Bazaar, School 33 Art Center's Open Studio Tour and the Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Parade.
The <a href="Baltimore%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Baltimore Symphony Orchestra</a> is an internationally renowned orchestra, founded in 1916 as a publicly funded municipal organization. The current music director is <a href="Marin%20Alsop">Marin Alsop</a>, a protégé of <a href="Leonard%20Bernstein">Leonard Bernstein</a>. <a href="Centerstage%20%28theater%29">Centerstage</a> is the premier theater company in the city and a regionally well-respected group. The <a href="Lyric%20Opera%20House">Lyric Opera House</a> is the home of <a href="Lyric%20Opera%20Baltimore">Lyric Opera Baltimore</a>, which operates there as part of the Patricia and Arthur Modell Performing Arts Center. <a href="The%20Baltimore%20Consort">The Baltimore Consort</a> has been a leading early music ensemble for over twenty-five years. The France-Merrick Performing Arts Center, home of the restored <a href="Thomas%20W.%20Lamb">Thomas W. Lamb</a>-designed <a href="Hippodrome%20Theatre%20%28Baltimore%29">Hippodrome Theatre</a>, has afforded Baltimore the opportunity to become a major regional player in the area of touring Broadway and other performing arts presentations. Renovating Baltimore's historic theatres have become widespread throughout the city such as the <a href="Everyman%20Theatre%2C%20Baltimore">Everyman</a>, Centre, <a href="Senator%20Theatre">Senator</a> and most recent <a href="Parkway%20Theatre%20%28Baltimore%29">Parkway</a> theatre. Other buildings have been reused such as the former <a href="Mercantile%20Trust%20and%20Deposit%20Company">Mercantile Deposit and Trust</a> Company bank building. It is now the Chesapeake Shakespeare Company Theater.
Baltimore also boasts a wide array of professional (non-touring) and community theater groups. Aside from Center Stage, resident troupes in the city include The Vagabond Players, the oldest continuously operating community theater group in the country, <a href="Everyman%20Theatre%2C%20Baltimore">Everyman Theatre</a>, Single Carrot Theatre, and Baltimore Theatre Festival. Community theaters in the city include Fells Point Community Theatre and the <a href="The%20Arena%20Players">Arena Players Inc.</a>, which is the nation's oldest continuously operating African American community theater. In 2009, the <a href="Baltimore%20Rock%20Opera%20Society">Baltimore Rock Opera Society</a>, an all-volunteer theatrical company, launched its first production.
Baltimore is home to the <a href="Pride%20of%20Baltimore%20Chorus">Pride of Baltimore Chorus</a>, a three-time international silver medalist women's chorus, affiliated with <a href="Sweet%20Adelines%20International">Sweet Adelines International</a>. The <a href="Maryland%20State%20Boychoir">Maryland State Boychoir</a> is located in the northeastern Baltimore neighborhood of Mayfield.
Baltimore is the home of non-profit <a href="chamber%20music">chamber music</a> organization Vivre Musicale. VM won a 2011–2012 award for Adventurous Programming from the <a href="American%20Society%20of%20Composers%2C%20Authors%20and%20Publishers">American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers</a> and <a href="Chamber%20Music%20America">Chamber Music America</a>.
The <a href="Peabody%20Institute">Peabody Institute</a>, located in the Mount Vernon neighborhood, is the oldest conservatory of music in the United States. Established in 1857, it is one of the most prestigious in the world, along with <a href="Juilliard%20School">Juilliard</a>, <a href="Eastman%20School%20of%20Music">Eastman</a>, and the <a href="Curtis%20Institute%20of%20Music">Curtis Institute</a>.
