The <a href="Morgan%20State%20University">Morgan State University</a> Choir is also one of the nation's most prestigious university choral ensembles. The city is home to the <a href="Baltimore%20School%20for%20the%20Arts">Baltimore School for the Arts</a>, a public high school in the Mount Vernon neighborhood of Baltimore. The institution is nationally recognized for its success in preparation for students entering music (vocal/instrumental), theatre (acting/theater production), dance, and visual arts.
In 1981, Baltimore hosted the first International Theater Festival, the first such festival in the country. Executive producer Al Kraizer staged 66 performances of nine shows by international <a href="theatre%20companies">theatre companies</a>, including from Ireland, the United Kingdom, South Africa and Israel. However, the festival proved to be expensive to mount, and the following year the festival was hosted in Denver, called the World Theatre Festival, at the <a href="Denver%20Center%20for%20Performing%20Arts">Denver Center for Performing Arts</a>, after the city had asked Kraizer to organize it.
In June 1986, the 20th Theatre of Nations, sponsored by the <a href="International%20Theatre%20Institute">International Theatre Institute</a>, was held in Baltimore – the first time it had been held in the U.S.
Sports.
Baseball.
Baltimore has a long and storied baseball history, including its distinction as the birthplace of <a href="Babe%20Ruth">Babe Ruth</a> in 1895. The original <a href="Baltimore%20Orioles%20%2819th%20century%29">19th century Baltimore Orioles</a> were one of the most successful early franchises, featuring numerous hall of famers during its years from 1882 to 1899.
As one of the eight inaugural American League franchises, the Baltimore Orioles played in the AL during the 1901 and 1902 seasons. The team moved to New York City before the 1903 season and was renamed the New York Highlanders, which later became the <a href="New%20York%20Yankees">New York Yankees</a>.
Ruth played for the <a href="Baltimore%20Orioles%20%28minor%20league%29">minor league Baltimore Orioles</a> team, which was active from 1903 to 1914. After playing one season in 1915 as the Richmond Climbers, the team returned the following year to Baltimore, where it played as the Orioles until 1953.
The team currently known as the <a href="Baltimore%20Orioles">Baltimore Orioles</a> has represented Major League Baseball locally since 1954 when the St. Louis Browns moved to the city of Baltimore. The Orioles advanced to the World Series in 1966, 1969, 1970, 1971, 1979 and 1983, winning three times (1966, 1970 and 1983), while making the playoffs all but one year (1972) from 1969 through 1974.
In 1995, local player (and later Hall of Famer) <a href="Cal%20Ripken%2C%20Jr.">Cal Ripken, Jr.</a> broke <a href="Lou%20Gehrig">Lou Gehrig</a>'s streak of 2,130 consecutive games played, for which Ripken was named <a href="Sportsman%20of%20the%20Year">Sportsman of the Year</a> by "<a href="Sports%20Illustrated">Sports Illustrated</a>" magazine. Six former Orioles players, including Ripken (2007), and two of the team's managers have been inducted into the <a href="National%20Baseball%20Hall%20of%20Fame%20and%20Museum">Baseball Hall of Fame</a>.
Since 1992, the Orioles' home ballpark has been <a href="Oriole%20Park%20at%20Camden%20Yards">Oriole Park at Camden Yards</a>, which has been hailed as one of the league's best since it opened.
Football.
Prior to an NFL team moving to Baltimore, there had been several attempts at a professional football team prior to the 1950s. Most were minor league or <a href="semi-professional">semi-professional</a> teams. The first major league to base a team in Baltimore was the <a href="All-America%20Football%20Conference">All-America Football Conference</a> (AAFC), which had a team named the <a href="Baltimore%20Colts%20%281947%E2%80%9350%29">Baltimore Colts</a>. The AAFC Colts played for three seasons in the AAFC (1947, 1948, and 1949), and when the AAFC folded following the 1949 season, moved to the NFL for a single year (1950) before going bankrupt. Three years later, the NFL's <a href="Dallas%20Texans%20%28NFL%29">Dallas Texans</a> would itself fold. Its assets and player contracts purchased by an ownership team headed by Baltimore businessman <a href="Carroll%20Rosenbloom">Carroll Rosenbloom</a>, who moved the team to Baltimore, establishing a new team also named the <a href="History%20of%20the%20Baltimore%20Colts">Baltimore Colts</a>. During the 1950s and 1960s, the Colts were one of the NFLs more successful franchises, led by <a href="Pro%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Pro Football Hall of Fame</a> quarterback <a href="Johnny%20Unitas">Johnny Unitas</a> who set a then-record of 47 consecutive games with a touchdown pass. The Colts advanced to the <a href="NFL%20Championship">NFL Championship</a> twice (1958 & 1959) and <a href="Super%20Bowl">Super Bowl</a> twice (1969 & 1971), winning all except <a href="Super%20Bowl%20III">Super Bowl III</a> in 1969. After the 1983 season, the team <a href="Baltimore%20Colts%20relocation%20to%20Indianapolis">left Baltimore for Indianapolis in 1984</a>, where they became the <a href="Indianapolis%20Colts">Indianapolis Colts</a>.
The NFL returned to Baltimore when the former <a href="Cleveland%20Browns%20relocation%20controversy">Cleveland Browns</a> moved to Baltimore to become the <a href="Baltimore%20Ravens">Baltimore Ravens</a> in 1996. Since then, the Ravens won a Super Bowl championship in <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXXV">2000</a> and <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLVII">2012</a>, six <a href="AFC%20North">AFC North</a> division championships (2003, 2006, 2011, 2012, 2018, and 2019), and appeared in four <a href="AFC%20Championship%20Game">AFC Championship Game</a>s (2000, 2008, 2011 and 2012).
Baltimore also hosted a <a href="Canadian%20Football%20League">Canadian Football League</a> franchise, the <a href="Baltimore%20Stallions">Baltimore Stallions</a> for the <a href="1994%20CFL%20season">1994</a> and <a href="1995%20CFL%20season">1995</a> seasons. Following the 1995 season, and ultimate end to the <a href="Canadian%20Football%20League%20in%20the%20United%20States">Canadian Football League in the United States</a> experiment, the team was sold and relocated to <a href="Montreal">Montreal</a>.
Other teams and events.
The first professional sports organization in the United States, <a href="Maryland%20Jockey%20Club">The Maryland Jockey Club</a>, was formed in Baltimore in 1743. <a href="Preakness%20Stakes">Preakness Stakes</a>, the second race in the <a href="United%20States%20Triple%20Crown%20of%20Thoroughbred%20Racing">United States Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing</a>, has been held every May at <a href="Pimlico%20Race%20Course">Pimlico Race Course</a> in Baltimore since 1873.
College <a href="lacrosse">lacrosse</a> is a common sport in the spring, as the <a href="Johns%20Hopkins%20Blue%20Jays">Johns Hopkins Blue Jays</a> men's lacrosse team has won 44 national championships, the most of any program in history. In addition, <a href="Loyola%20University%20Maryland">Loyola University</a> won its first men's <a href="NCAA">NCAA</a> lacrosse championship in 2012.
The <a href="Baltimore%20Blast">Baltimore Blast</a> are a professional arena <a href="soccer">soccer</a> team that play in the <a href="Major%20Arena%20Soccer%20League">Major Arena Soccer League</a> at the <a href="SECU%20Arena">SECU Arena</a> on the campus of <a href="Towson%20University">Towson University</a>. The Blast have won nine championships in various leagues, including the MASL. A previous entity of the <a href="Baltimore%20Blast%20%281980%E2%80%9392%29">Blast</a> played in the <a href="Major%20Indoor%20Soccer%20League%20%281978%E2%80%9392%29">Major Indoor Soccer League</a> from 1980 to 1992, winning one championship. The Baltimore Kings, a Baltimore Blast affiliate, joined MASL 3 in 2021 to begin play in 2022.
The <a href="FC%20Baltimore">FC Baltimore 1729</a> is a semi-professional soccer club playing for <a href="National%20Premier%20Soccer%20League">NPSL league</a>, with the goal of bringing a community-oriented competitive soccer experience to the city of Baltimore. Their inaugural season started on May 11, 2018, and they play home games at <a href="Community%20College%20of%20Baltimore%20County%23Essex%20Campus">CCBC Essex Field</a>.
The <a href="Baltimore%20Blues">Baltimore Blues</a> are a semi-professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> club which began competition in the <a href="USA%20Rugby%20League">USA Rugby League</a> in 2012. The <a href="Baltimore%20Bohemians">Baltimore Bohemians</a> are an American <a href="Football%20%28soccer%29">soccer club</a>. They compete in the <a href="USL%20Premier%20Development%20League">USL Premier Development League</a>, the fourth tier of the <a href="American%20Soccer%20Pyramid">American Soccer Pyramid</a>. Their inaugural season started in the spring of 2012.
The <a href="Baltimore%20Grand%20Prix">Baltimore Grand Prix</a> debuted along the streets of the Inner Harbor section of the city's downtown on September 2–4, 2011. The event played host to the <a href="American%20Le%20Mans%20Series">American Le Mans Series</a> on Saturday and the <a href="IndyCar%20Series">IndyCar Series</a> on Sunday. Support races from smaller series were also held, including <a href="Indy%20Lights">Indy Lights</a>. After three consecutive years, on September 13, 2013, it was announced that the event would not be held in 2014 or 2015 due to scheduling conflicts.
The athletic equipment company <a href="Under%20Armour">Under Armour</a> is also based out of Baltimore. Founded in 1996 by <a href="Kevin%20Plank">Kevin Plank</a>, a <a href="University%20of%20Maryland">University of Maryland</a> alumnus, the company's headquarters are located in Tide Point, adjacent to <a href="Fort%20McHenry">Fort McHenry</a> and the <a href="Domino%20Sugar">Domino Sugar</a> factory. The <a href="Baltimore%20Marathon">Baltimore Marathon</a> is the flagship race of several races. The marathon begins at the <a href="Camden%20Yards">Camden Yards</a> sports complex and travels through many diverse neighborhoods of Baltimore, including the scenic Inner Harbor waterfront area, historic Federal Hill, <a href="Fells%20Point">Fells Point</a>, and <a href="Canton%2C%20Baltimore">Canton, Baltimore</a>. The race then proceeds to other important focal points of the city such as <a href="Patterson%20Park">Patterson Park</a>, Clifton Park, Lake Montebello, the Charles Village neighborhood and the western edge of downtown. After winding through 42.195 kilometres (26.219 mi) of Baltimore, the race ends at virtually the same point at which it starts.
The <a href="Baltimore%20Brigade">Baltimore Brigade</a> were an <a href="Arena%20Football%20League">Arena Football League</a> team based in Baltimore that from 2017 to 2019 played at <a href="Royal%20Farms%20Arena">Royal Farms Arena</a>. The team ceased operations along with the league in 2019.
Parks and recreation.
The City of Baltimore boasts over of parkland. The Baltimore City Department of Recreation and Parks manages the majority of parks and recreational facilities in the city including <a href="Patterson%20Park">Patterson Park</a>, <a href="Federal%20Hill%20Park">Federal Hill Park</a>, and <a href="Druid%20Hill%20Park">Druid Hill Park</a>. The city is also home to <a href="Fort%20McHenry%20National%20Monument%20and%20Historic%20Shrine">Fort McHenry National Monument and Historic Shrine</a>, a coastal star-shaped fort best known for its role in the War of 1812. , <a href="Trust%20for%20Public%20Land">The Trust for Public Land</a>, a national land conservation organization, ranks Baltimore 40th among the 75 largest U.S. cities.
Politics and government.
Baltimore is an <a href="Independent%20city%20%28United%20States%29">independent city</a>, and not part of any <a href="county%20%28United%20States%29">county</a>. For most governmental purposes under Maryland law, Baltimore City is treated as a county-level entity. The <a href="United%20States%20Census%20Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a> uses counties as the basic unit for presentation of statistical information in the United States, and treats Baltimore as a county equivalent for those purposes.
Baltimore has been a <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democratic</a> stronghold for over 150 years, with Democrats dominating every level of government. In virtually all elections, the Democratic primary is the real contest. As of the 2020 elections, registered Democrats outnumbered registered <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republicans</a> by almost 10-to-1. No Republican has been elected to the City Council since 1939, and the city's last Republican mayor, <a href="Theodore%20McKeldin">Theodore McKeldin</a>, left office in 1967. No Republican candidate since then has received 25 percent or more of the vote. In the <a href="2016%20Baltimore%20mayoral%20election">2016</a> and <a href="2020%20Baltimore%20mayoral%20election">2020 mayoral election</a>s, the Republicans were pushed into third place by write-in and independent candidates, respectively.
The city hosted the first six <a href="Democratic%20National%20Convention">Democratic National Convention</a>s, from 1832 through 1852, and hosted the DNC again in <a href="1860%20Democratic%20National%20Convention">1860</a>, <a href="1872%20Democratic%20National%20Convention">1872</a>, and <a href="1912%20Democratic%20National%20Convention">1912</a>.
City government.
Mayor.
<a href="Brandon%20Scott">Brandon Scott</a> is the current <a href="mayor%20of%20Baltimore">mayor of Baltimore</a>. He was elected in 2020 and took office on December 8, 2020. Scott succeeded <a href="Jack%20Young%20%28politician%29">Jack Young</a> who had been mayor since May 2, 2019 upon the resignation of <a href="Catherine%20Pugh">Catherine Pugh</a>. Prior to Pugh's official resignation, Young was the president of the <a href="Baltimore%20City%20Council">Baltimore City Council</a> and had been the acting mayor since April 2.
<a href="Catherine%20Pugh">Catherine Pugh</a> became the Democratic nominee for mayor in 2016 and won the <a href="2016%20Baltimore%20mayoral%20election">mayoral election in 2016</a> with 57.1% of the vote; Pugh took office as mayor on December 6, 2016. Pugh took a leave of absence in April 2019 due to health concerns, then officially resigned from office on May 2. The resignation coincided with a scandal over a "self-dealing" book-sales arrangement.
<a href="Stephanie%20Rawlings-Blake">Stephanie Rawlings-Blake</a> assumed the office of Mayor on February 4, 2010, when predecessor Dixon's resignation became effective. Rawlings-Blake had been serving as City Council President at the time. She was elected to a full term in 2011, defeating Pugh in the primary election and receiving 84% of the vote.
<a href="Sheila%20Dixon">Sheila Dixon</a> became the first female mayor of Baltimore on January 17, 2007. As the former City Council President, she assumed the office of Mayor when former Mayor <a href="Martin%20O%27Malley">Martin O'Malley</a> took office as Governor of Maryland. On November 6, 2007, Dixon won the <a href="Baltimore%20mayoral%20election%2C%202007">Baltimore mayoral election</a>. Mayor Dixon's administration ended less than three years after her election, the result of a criminal investigation that began in 2006 while she was still City Council President. She was convicted on a single misdemeanor charge of <a href="embezzlement">embezzlement</a> on December 1, 2009. A month later, Dixon made an <a href="Alford%20plea">Alford plea</a> to a <a href="perjury">perjury</a> charge and agreed to resign from office; Maryland, like most states, does not allow convicted felons to hold office.
Baltimore City Council.
Grassroots pressure for reform, voiced as <a href="Question%20P">Question P</a>, restructured the city council in November 2002, against the will of the mayor, the council president, and the majority of the council. A coalition of union and community groups, organized by the <a href="Association%20of%20Community%20Organizations%20for%20Reform%20Now">Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now</a> (ACORN), backed the effort.
The <a href="Baltimore%20City%20Council">Baltimore City Council</a> is now made up of 14 single-member districts and one elected at-large council president. Current members of the council are <a href="Nick%20Mosby">Nick Mosby</a>, <a href="Danielle%20McCray">Danielle McCray</a>, <a href="Zeke%20Cohen">Zeke Cohen</a>, <a href="Ryan%20Dorsey">Ryan Dorsey</a>, <a href="Mark%20Conway">Mark Conway</a>, <a href="Isaac%20Schleifer">Isaac Schleifer</a>, <a href="Sharon%20Middleton">Sharon Middleton</a>, <a href="James%20Torrence">James Torrence</a>, <a href="Kristerfer%20Burnett">Kristerfer Burnett</a>, <a href="John%20Bullock%20%28Maryland%20politician%29">John Bullock</a>, <a href="Phylicia%20Porter">Phylicia Porter</a>, <a href="Eric%20Costello">Eric Costello</a>, <a href="Robert%20Stokes%2C%20Sr.">Robert Stokes, Sr.</a>, <a href="Antonio%20Glover">Antonio Glover</a>, and <a href="Odette%20Ramos">Odette Ramos</a>. <a href="Nick%20Mosby">Nick Mosby</a> has been the council president since November 2020, when he was elected to succeed the role from Mayor <a href="Brandon%20Scott">Brandon Scott</a>.
Law enforcement.
The <a href="Baltimore%20Police%20Department">Baltimore City Police Department</a>, founded 1784 as a "Night City Watch" and day Constables system and later reorganized as a City Department in 1853, with a following reorganization under State of Maryland supervision in 1859, with appointments made by the <a href="Governor%20of%20Maryland">Governor of Maryland</a> after a disturbing period of civic and elections violence with riots in the later part of the decade, is the current primary law enforcement agency serving the citizens of the City of Baltimore. Campus and building security for the city's <a href="Baltimore%20City%20Public%20Schools">public schools</a> is provided by the Baltimore City Public Schools Police, established in the 1970s.
In the period of 2011–2015, 120 lawsuits were brought against Baltimore police for alleged brutality and misconduct. The Freddie Gray settlement of $6.4 million exceeds the combined total settlements of the 120 lawsuits, as state law caps such payments.
The <a href="Maryland%20Transportation%20Authority%20Police">Maryland Transportation Authority Police</a> under the <a href="Maryland%20Department%20of%20Transportation">Maryland Department of Transportation</a>, (originally established as the "Baltimore Harbor Tunnel Police" when opened in 1957) is the primary law enforcement agency on the <a href="Fort%20McHenry%20Tunnel%20Thruway">Fort McHenry Tunnel Thruway</a> (Interstate 95), the <a href="Baltimore%20Harbor%20Tunnel%20Thruway">Baltimore Harbor Tunnel Thruway</a> (Interstate 895), which go under the Northwest Branch of the <a href="Patapsco%20River">Patapsco River</a>, and <a href="Interstate%20395%20%28Maryland%29">Interstate 395</a>, which has three ramp bridges crossing the Middle Branch of the <a href="Patapsco%20River">Patapsco River</a> which are under <a href="Maryland%20Transportation%20Authority">MdTA</a> jurisdiction, the <a href="Baltimore-Washington%20International%20Airport">Baltimore-Washington International Airport</a>, (BWI) and have limited concurrent jurisdiction with the <a href="Baltimore%20Police%20Department">Baltimore City Police Department</a> under a "<a href="memorandum%20of%20understanding">memorandum of understanding</a>".
Law enforcement on the fleet of transit buses and transit rail systems serving Baltimore is the responsibility of the <a href="Maryland%20Transit%20Administration%20Police">Maryland Transit Administration Police</a>, which is part of the Maryland Transit Administration of the state <a href="Maryland%20Department%20of%20Transportation">Department of Transportation</a>. The MTA Police also share jurisdiction authority with the Baltimore City Police, governed by a memorandum of understanding.
As the enforcement arm of the Baltimore circuit and district court system, the <a href="Baltimore%20City%20Sheriff%27s%20Office%20%28Maryland%29">Baltimore City Sheriff's Office</a>, created by state constitutional amendment in 1844, is responsible for the security of city courthouses and property, service of court-ordered writs, protective and peace orders, warrants, tax levies, prisoner transportation and traffic enforcement. Deputy Sheriffs are sworn law enforcement officials, with full arrest authority granted by the constitution of Maryland, the <a href="Maryland%20Police%20and%20Correctional%20Training%20Commission">Maryland Police and Correctional Training Commission</a> and the Sheriff of the City of Baltimore.
The <a href="United%20States%20Coast%20Guard">United States Coast Guard</a>, operating out of their shipyard and facility (since 1899) at Arundel Cove on <a href="Curtis%20Creek">Curtis Creek</a>, (off Pennington Avenue extending to Hawkins Point Road/Fort Smallwood Road) in the <a href="Curtis%20Bay%2C%20Baltimore">Curtis Bay</a> section of southern Baltimore City and adjacent northern Anne Arundel County. The U.S.C.G. also operates and maintains a presence on Baltimore and Maryland waterways in the <a href="Patapsco%20River">Patapsco River</a> and <a href="Chesapeake%20Bay">Chesapeake Bay</a>. "Sector Baltimore" is responsible for commanding law enforcement and search & rescue units as well as aids to navigation.
Baltimore City Fire Department.
The city of Baltimore is protected by the over 1,800 professional firefighters of the Baltimore City Fire Department (BCFD), which was founded in December 1858 and began operating the following year. Replacing several warring independent volunteer companies since the 1770s and the confusion resulting from <a href="Know-Nothing%20Riot%20of%201856">a riot</a> involving the "<a href="Know-Nothing">Know-Nothing</a>" political party two years before, the establishment of a unified professional fire fighting force was a major advance in urban governance. The BCFD operates out of 37 fire stations located throughout the city and has a long history and sets of traditions in its various houses and divisions.
State government.
Since the legislative <a href="redistricting">redistricting</a> in 2002, Baltimore has had six legislative districts located entirely within its boundaries, giving the city six seats in the 47-member <a href="Maryland%20Senate">Maryland Senate</a> and 18 in the 141-member <a href="Maryland%20House%20of%20Delegates">Maryland House of Delegates</a>. During the previous 10-year period, Baltimore had four legislative districts within the city limits, but four others overlapped the Baltimore County line. , all of Baltimore's state senators and delegates were Democrats.
Federal government.
Three of the state's eight <a href="congressional%20district">congressional district</a>s include portions of Baltimore: the <a href="Maryland%27s%202nd%20congressional%20district">2nd</a>, represented by <a href="Dutch%20Ruppersberger">Dutch Ruppersberger</a>; the <a href="Maryland%27s%203rd%20congressional%20district">3rd</a>, represented by <a href="John%20Sarbanes">John Sarbanes</a>; and the <a href="Maryland%27s%207th%20congressional%20district">7th</a>, represented by <a href="Kweisi%20Mfume">Kweisi Mfume</a>. All three are Democrats; a Republican has not represented a significant portion of Baltimore in Congress since <a href="John%20Boynton%20Philip%20Clayton%20Hill">John Boynton Philip Clayton Hill</a> represented the 3rd District in 1927, and has not represented any of Baltimore since the <a href="Eastern%20Shore%20of%20Maryland">Eastern Shore</a>-based 1st District lost its share of Baltimore after the 2000 census; it was represented by Republican <a href="Wayne%20Gilchrest">Wayne Gilchrest</a> at the time.
Maryland's senior <a href="United%20States%20senator">United States senator</a>, <a href="Ben%20Cardin">Ben Cardin</a>, is from Baltimore. He is one of three people in the last four decades to have represented the 3rd District before being elected to the <a href="United%20States%20Senate">United States Senate</a>. <a href="Paul%20Sarbanes">Paul Sarbanes</a> represented the 3rd from 1971 until 1977, when he was elected to the first of five terms in the Senate. Sarbanes was succeeded by <a href="Barbara%20Mikulski">Barbara Mikulski</a>, who represented the 3rd from 1977 to 1987. Mikulski was succeeded by Cardin, who held the seat until handing it to John Sarbanes upon his election to the Senate in 2007.
The <a href="United%20States%20Postal%20Service">Postal Service</a>'s Baltimore Main Post Office is located at 900 East Fayette Street in the <a href="Jonestown%2C%20Baltimore">Jonestown</a> area.
The national headquarters for the <a href="United%20States%20Social%20Security%20Administration">United States Social Security Administration</a> is located in Woodlawn, just outside of Baltimore.
Education.
Colleges and universities.
Baltimore is the home of numerous places of higher learning, both public and private. 100,000 college students from around the country attend Baltimore City's 12 accredited two-year or four-year colleges and universities. Among them are:
Primary and secondary schools.
The city's public schools are managed by <a href="Baltimore%20City%20Public%20Schools">Baltimore City Public Schools</a> and include schools that have been well known in the area: <a href="Carver%20Vocational%20Technical%20High%20School">Carver Vocational-Technical High School</a>, the first African American vocational high school and center that was established in the state of Maryland; <a href="Digital%20Harbor%20High%20School">Digital Harbor High School</a>, one of the secondary schools that emphasizes <a href="information%20technology">information technology</a>; <a href="Lake%20Clifton%20Eastern%20High%20School">Lake Clifton Eastern High School</a>, which is the largest school campus in Baltimore City of physical size; the historic <a href="Frederick%20Douglass%20Senior%20High%20School%20%28Baltimore%2C%20Maryland%29">Frederick Douglass High School</a>, which is the second oldest African American high school in the United States; <a href="Baltimore%20City%20College">Baltimore City College</a>, the third oldest public high school in the country; and <a href="Western%20High%20School%20%28Baltimore%2C%20Maryland%29">Western High School</a>, the oldest public all-girls school in the nation. Baltimore City College (also known as "City") and <a href="Baltimore%20Polytechnic%20Institute">Baltimore Polytechnic Institute</a> (also known as "Poly") share the nation's second-oldest high school <a href="Baltimore%20City%20College%20football">football rivalry</a>.
Transportation.
The city of Baltimore has a higher-than-average percentage of households without a car. In 2015, 30.7 percent of Baltimore households lacked a car, which decreased slightly to 28.9 percent in 2016. The national average was 8.7 percent in 2016. Baltimore averaged 1.65 cars per household in 2016, compared to a national average of 1.8.
Roads and highways.
Baltimore's highway growth has done much to influence the development of the city and its suburbs. The first <a href="limited-access%20highway">limited-access highway</a> serving Baltimore was the <a href="Baltimore%E2%80%93Washington%20Parkway">Baltimore–Washington Parkway</a>, which opened in stages between 1950 and 1954. Maintenance of it is split: the half closest to Baltimore is maintained by the state of Maryland, and the half closest to Washington by the <a href="National%20Park%20Service">National Park Service</a>. Trucks are only permitted to use the northern part of the parkway. Trucks (tractor-trailers) continued to use <a href="U.S.%20Route%201%20in%20Maryland">U.S. Route 1</a> (US 1) until <a href="Interstate%2095%20in%20Maryland">Interstate 95</a> (I-95) between Baltimore and Washington opened in 1971.
The Interstate highways serving Baltimore are <a href="Interstate%2070%20in%20Maryland">I-70</a>, I-83 (the Jones Falls Expressway), I-95, <a href="Interstate%20395%20%28Maryland%29">I-395</a>, <a href="Interstate%20695%20%28Maryland%29">I-695</a> (the Baltimore Beltway), <a href="Interstate%20795%20%28Maryland%29">I-795</a> (the Northwest Expressway), <a href="Interstate%20895%20%28Maryland%29">I-895</a> (the Harbor Tunnel Thruway), and <a href="Interstate%2097">I-97</a>. The city's mainline Interstate highways—I-95, I-83, and I-70—do not directly connect to each other, and in the case of I-70 end at a park and ride lot just inside the city limits, because of <a href="highway%20revolts">freeway revolts</a> in Baltimore. These revolts were led primarily by <a href="Barbara%20Mikulski">Barbara Mikulski</a>, a former <a href="United%20States%20senator">United States senator</a> for Maryland, which resulted in the abandonment of the original plan. There are two tunnels traversing Baltimore Harbor within the city limits: the four-bore <a href="Fort%20McHenry%20Tunnel">Fort McHenry Tunnel</a> (opened in 1985 and serving I-95) and the two-bore <a href="Baltimore%20Harbor%20Tunnel">Harbor Tunnel</a> (opened in 1957 and serving I-895). The Baltimore Beltway crosses south of Baltimore Harbor over the <a href="Francis%20Scott%20Key%20Bridge%20%28Baltimore%29">Francis Scott Key Bridge</a>.
The first interstate highway built in Baltimore was I-83, called the Jones Falls Expressway (first portion built in the early 1960s). Running from the downtown toward the northwest (NNW), it was built through a natural corridor, which meant that no residents or housing were directly affected. A planned section from what is now its southern terminus to I-95 was abandoned. Its route through parkland received criticism.
Planning for the Baltimore Beltway antedates the creation of the <a href="Interstate%20Highway%20System">Interstate Highway System</a>. The first portion completed was a small strip connecting the two sections of I-83, the Baltimore-Harrisburg Expressway and the Jones Falls Expressway.
The only <a href="United%20States%20Numbered%20Highways">U.S. Highways</a> in the city are US 1, which bypasses downtown, and <a href="U.S.%20Route%2040%20in%20Maryland">US 40</a>, which crosses downtown from east to west. Both run along major surface streets; however, US 40 utilizes a small section of a freeway cancelled in the 1970s in the west side of the city originally intended for <a href="Interstate%20170%20%28Maryland%29">Interstate 170</a>. State routes in the city also travel along surface streets, with the exception of <a href="Maryland%20Route%20295">Maryland Route 295</a>, which carries the Baltimore–Washington Parkway.
The Baltimore City Department of Transportation (BCDOT) is responsible for several functions of the road transportation system in Baltimore, including repairing roads, sidewalks, and alleys; road signs; street lights; and managing the flow of transportation systems. In addition, the agency is in charge of vehicle towing and <a href="traffic%20camera">traffic camera</a>s. BCDOT maintains all streets within the city of Baltimore. These include all streets that are marked as state and U.S. highways as well as the portions of I-83 and I-70 within the city limits. The only highways within the city that are not maintained by BCDOT are I-95, I-395, I-695, and I-895; those four highways are maintained by the Maryland Transportation Authority.
Transit systems.
Public transit.
Public transit in Baltimore is mostly provided by the <a href="Maryland%20Transit%20Administration">Maryland Transit Administration</a> (abbreviated "MTA Maryland") and <a href="Charm%20City%20Circulator">Charm City Circulator</a>. MTA Maryland operates a comprehensive <a href="MTA%20Maryland%20bus%20service">bus</a> network, including many local, express, and commuter buses, <a href="Baltimore%20Light%20RailLink">a light rail network</a> connecting <a href="Hunt%20Valley%2C%20Maryland">Hunt Valley</a> in the north to BWI Airport and <a href="Cromwell%20Station%20/%20Glen%20Burnie%20%28Baltimore%20Light%20Rail%20station%29">Cromwell</a> (<a href="Glen%20Burnie%2C%20Maryland">Glen Burnie</a>) in the south, and a <a href="Baltimore%20Metro%20SubwayLink">subway line</a> between <a href="Owings%20Mills%2C%20Maryland">Owings Mills</a> and Johns Hopkins Hospital. A proposed rail line, known as the <a href="Red%20Line%20%28Baltimore%29">Red Line</a>, which would link the Social Security Administration to <a href="Johns%20Hopkins%20Bayview%20Medical%20Center">Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center</a> and perhaps the <a href="Canton%2C%20Baltimore">Canton</a> and <a href="Dundalk%2C%20Maryland">Dundalk</a> communities, was cancelled by Governor <a href="Larry%20Hogan">Larry Hogan</a>; a proposal to extend Baltimore's existing subway line to <a href="Morgan%20State%20University">Morgan State University</a>, known as the <a href="Green%20Line%20%28Baltimore%29">Green Line</a>, is in the planning stages.
The Charm City Circulator (CCC), a <a href="shuttle%20bus%20service">shuttle bus service</a> operated by Veolia Transportation for the Baltimore Department of Transportation, began operating in the downtown area in January 2010. Funded partly by a 16 percent increase in the city's parking fees, the circulator provides free bus service seven days a week, picking up passengers every 15 minutes at designated stops during service hours.
The CCC's first bus line, the Orange route, travels between Hollins Market and Harbor East. Its Purple route, launched June 7, 2010, operates between Fort Avenue and 33rd St. The Green route runs between Johns Hopkins and City Hall. The Charm City Circulator operates a fleet of diesel and hybrid vehicles built by DesignLine, Orion, and Van Hool.
Baltimore also has a <a href="water%20taxi">water taxi</a> service, operated by <a href="Baltimore%20Water%20Taxi">Baltimore Water Taxi</a>. The water taxi's six routes provide service throughout the city's harbor, and was purchased by <a href="Under%20Armour">Under Armour</a> CEO <a href="Kevin%20Plank">Kevin Plank</a>'s Sagamore Ventures in 2016.
In June 2017, The BaltimoreLink started operating; it is the redesign of the region's initial bus system. The BaltimoreLink runs through downtown Baltimore every 10 minutes via color-coded, high-frequency CityLink routes.
Intercity rail.
Baltimore is a top destination for <a href="Amtrak">Amtrak</a> along the <a href="Northeast%20Corridor">Northeast Corridor</a>. Baltimore's <a href="Pennsylvania%20Station%20%28Baltimore%29">Penn Station</a> is one of the busiest in the country. In FY 2014, Penn Station was ranked the <a href="List%20of%20busiest%20Amtrak%20stations">seventh-busiest</a> rail station in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> by number of passengers served each year. The building sits on a raised "island" of sorts between two open trenches, one for the Jones Falls Expressway and the other for the tracks of the Northeast Corridor (NEC). The NEC approaches from the south through the two-track, <a href="Baltimore%20and%20Potomac%20Tunnel">Baltimore and Potomac Tunnel</a>, which opened in 1873 and whose limit, sharp curves, and steep grades make it one of the NEC's worst bottlenecks. The NEC's northern approach is the 1873 <a href="Union%20Tunnel%20%28Baltimore%29">Union Tunnel</a>, which has one <a href="single%20track%20%28rail%29">single-track</a> bore and one <a href="double%20track">double-track</a> bore.
Just outside the city, <a href="BWI%20Rail%20Station">Baltimore/Washington International (BWI) Thurgood Marshall Airport Rail Station</a> is another stop. Amtrak's "<a href="Acela%20Express">Acela Express</a>", "<a href="Palmetto%20%28train%29">Palmetto</a>", "<a href="Carolinian%20%28train%29">Carolinian</a>", "<a href="Silver%20Star%20%28Amtrak%20train%29">Silver Star</a>", "<a href="Silver%20Meteor">Silver Meteor</a>", "<a href="Vermonter%20%28train%29">Vermonter</a>", "<a href="Crescent%20%28train%29">Crescent</a>", and "<a href="Northeast%20Regional">Northeast Regional</a>" trains are the scheduled passenger train services that stop in the city. Additionally, <a href="MARC%20Train">MARC</a> commuter rail service connects the city's two main intercity rail stations, Camden Station and Penn Station, with Washington, D.C.'s <a href="Union%20Station%20%28Washington%2C%20D.C.%29">Union Station</a> as well as stops in between. The MARC consists of 3 lines; the Brunswick, Camden and Penn. On December 7, 2013, the Penn Line began weekend service.
Airports.
Baltimore is served by two airports, both operated by the Maryland Aviation Administration, which is part of the <a href="Maryland%20Department%20of%20Transportation">Maryland Department of Transportation</a>. <a href="Baltimore%E2%80%93Washington%20International%20Thurgood%20Marshall%20Airport">Baltimore–Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport</a>, generally known as "BWI", lies about to the south of Baltimore in neighboring Anne Arundel County. The airport is named after <a href="Thurgood%20Marshall">Thurgood Marshall</a>, a Baltimore native who was the first African American to serve on the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20the%20United%20States">Supreme Court of the United States</a>. In terms of passenger traffic, BWI is the 22nd busiest airport in the United States. As of calendar year 2014, BWI is the largest, by passenger count, of three major airports serving the <a href="Baltimore%E2%80%93Washington%20Metropolitan%20Area">Baltimore–Washington Metropolitan Area</a>. It is accessible by I-95 and the Baltimore–Washington Parkway via <a href="Interstate%20195%20%28Maryland%29">Interstate 195</a>, the <a href="Baltimore%20Light%20Rail">Baltimore Light Rail</a>, and Amtrak and MARC Train at <a href="BWI%20Rail%20Station">BWI Rail Station</a>.
Baltimore is also served by <a href="Martin%20State%20Airport">Martin State Airport</a>, a <a href="general%20aviation">general aviation</a> facility, to the northeast in Baltimore County. Martin State Airport is linked to <a href="downtown%20Baltimore">downtown Baltimore</a> by <a href="Maryland%20Route%20150">Maryland Route 150</a> (Eastern Avenue) and by MARC Train at <a href="Martin%20State%20Airport%20%28MARC%20station%29">its own station</a>.
Pedestrians and bicycles.
Baltimore has a comprehensive system of bicycle routes in the city. These routes are not numbered, but are typically denoted with green signs displaying a silhouette of a bicycle upon an outline of the city's border, and denote the distance to destinations, much like bicycle routes in the rest of the state. The roads carrying bicycle routes are also labelled with either bike lanes, sharrows, or Share the Road signs. Many of these routes pass through the downtown area. The network of bicycle lanes in the city continues to expand, with over added between 2006 and 2014. Alongside bike lanes, Baltimore has also built <a href="bike%20boulevard">bike boulevard</a>s, starting with Guilford Avenue in 2012.
Baltimore currently has three major trail systems within the city. The <a href="Gwynns%20Falls%20Trail">Gwynns Falls Trail</a> runs from the Inner Harbor to the I-70 Park and Ride, passing through <a href="Gwynns%20Falls%20Park">Gwynns Falls Park</a> and possessing numerous branches. There are also many pedestrian hiking trails traversing the park. The <a href="Jones%20Falls%20Trail">Jones Falls Trail</a> currently runs from the Inner Harbor to the Cylburn Arboretum; however, it is currently undergoing expansion. Long-term plans call for it to extend to the <a href="Mount%20Washington%20%28Baltimore%20Light%20Rail%20station%29">Mount Washington Light Rail Stop</a>, and possibly as far north as the Falls Road stop to connect to the Robert E. Lee boardwalk north of the city. It will also incorporate a spur alongside Western Run. The two aforementioned trails carry sections of the <a href="East%20Coast%20Greenway">East Coast Greenway</a> through the city. There is also the Herring Run Trail, which runs from <a href="Maryland%20Route%20147">Harford Road</a> east to its end beyond Sinclair Lane, utilizing Herring Run Park; long-term plans also call for its extension to <a href="Morgan%20State%20University">Morgan State University</a> and north to points beyond. Other major bicycle projects include a protected cycle track installed on both Maryland Avenue and Mount Royal Avenue, expected to become the backbone of a downtown bicycle network. Installation for the cycletracks is expected in 2014 and 2016, respectively.
In addition to the bicycle trails and cycletracks, Baltimore has the Stony Run Trail, a walking path that will eventually connect from the Jones Falls north to Northern Parkway, utilizing much of the old Ma and Pa Railroad corridor inside the city. In 2011, the city undertook a campaign to reconstruct many sidewalk ramps in the city, coinciding with mass resurfacing of the city's streets. A 2011 study by <a href="Walk%20Score">Walk Score</a> ranked Baltimore the 14th most walkable of fifty largest U.S. cities.
Port of Baltimore.
The port was founded in 1706, preceding the founding of Baltimore. The Maryland colonial legislature made the area near <a href="Locust%20Point%2C%20Baltimore">Locust Point</a> as the <a href="port%20of%20entry">port of entry</a> for the <a href="tobacco">tobacco</a> trade with England. Fells Point, the deepest point in the natural harbor, soon became the colony's main ship building center, later on becoming leader in the construction of <a href="Baltimore%20Clipper">clipper ships</a>.
After Baltimore's founding, mills were built behind the wharves. The <a href="California%20Gold%20Rush">California Gold Rush</a> led to many orders for fast vessels; many overland pioneers also relied upon canned goods from Baltimore. After the Civil War, a coffee ship was designed here for trade with <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>. At the end of the nineteenth century, European ship lines had terminals for immigrants. The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad made the port a major <a href="transshipment">transshipment</a> point. Currently the port has major <a href="roll-on/roll-off">roll-on/roll-off</a> facilities, as well as bulk facilities, especially steel handling.
<a href="Water%20taxi">Water taxi</a>s also operate in the Inner Harbor. Governor Ehrlich participated in naming the port after <a href="Helen%20Delich%20Bentley">Helen Delich Bentley</a> during the 300th anniversary of the port.
In 2007, <a href="Duke%20Realty">Duke Realty</a> Corporation began a new development near the Port of Baltimore, named the Chesapeake Commerce Center. This new industrial park is located on the site of a former General Motors plant. The total project comprises in eastern Baltimore City, and the site will yield of warehouse/distribution and office space. Chesapeake Commerce Center has direct access to two major Interstate highways (<a href="I-95">I-95</a> and <a href="Interstate%20895%20%28Maryland%29">I-895</a>) and is located adjacent to two of the major Port of Baltimore terminals. The Port of Baltimore is one of two seaports on the U.S. East Coast with a dredge to accommodate the largest shipping vessels.
Along with cargo terminals, the port also has a passenger cruise terminal, which offers year-round trips on several lines, including Royal Caribbean's Grandeur of the Seas and Carnival's Pride. Overall five cruise lines have operated out of the port to the Bahamas and the Caribbean, while some ships traveled to New England and Canada. The terminal has become an embarkation point where passengers have the opportunity to park and board next to the ship visible from Interstate 95. Passengers from Pennsylvania, New York and New Jersey make up a third of the volume, with travelers from Maryland, Virginia, the District and even Ohio and the Carolinas making up the rest.
Environment.
Baltimore's Inner Harbor, known for its skyline waterscape and its tourist-friendly areas, was horribly polluted. The waterway was often filled with garbage after heavy rainstorms, failing its 2014 water quality report card. The Waterfront Partnership of Baltimore took steps to remediate the waterways, in hopes that the harbor would be fishable and swimmable once again.
Trash interceptors.
Baltimore has two water wheel trash interceptors for removing garbage in area waterways. One is at the mouth of <a href="Jones%20Falls">Jones Falls</a> in Baltimore's Inner Harbor, dubbed "Mr. Trash Wheel." Another, "Professor Trash Wheel" was added at Harris Creek in the <a href="Canton%2C%20Baltimore">Canton</a> neighborhood in 2016, with "Captain Trash Wheel" following at Mason Creek in 2018 and "Gwynnda, the Good Wheel of the West" at the mouth of the <a href="Gwynns%20Falls">Gwynns Falls</a> in 2021. A February 2015 agreement with a local waste-to-energy plant is believed to make Baltimore the first city to use reclaimed waterway debris to generate electricity.
Other water pollution control.
In August 2010, the National Aquarium assembled, planted, and launched a <a href="floating%20island">floating wetland island</a> designed by Biohabitats in Baltimore's Inner Harbor. Hundreds of years ago Baltimore's harbor shoreline would have been lined with tidal <a href="wetland">wetland</a>s. Floating wetlands provide many environmental benefits to water quality and habitat enhancement, which is why the Waterfront Partnership of Baltimore has included them in their Healthy Harbor Initiative pilot projects. Biohabitats also developed a concept to transform a dilapidated wharf into a living pier that cleans Harbor water, provides habitat and is an aesthetic attraction. Currently under design, the top of the pier will become a <a href="Constructed%20wetland">constructed tidal wetland</a>.
Other projects to improve water quality include the Blue Alleys project, expanded street sweeping, and stream restoration.
Media.
Baltimore's main media outlet since 2010 is Baltimore Brew, edited by Fern Shen and Mark Reutter, investigative journalists of the Washington Post and Baltimore Sun, respectively. "<a href="The%20Baltimore%20Sun">The Baltimore Sun</a>" was sold by its Baltimore owners in 1986 to the Times Mirror Company, which was bought by the <a href="Tribune%20Company">Tribune Company</a> in 2000. Since the recent sale, The Baltimore Sun prints some local news along with regional and national articles. The "<a href="Baltimore%20News-American">Baltimore News-American</a>", another long-running paper that competed with the Sun, ceased publication in 1986.
The city is home to the <a href="Baltimore%20Afro-American">Baltimore Afro-American</a>, an influential African American newspaper founded in 1892.
In 2006, "<a href="The%20Baltimore%20Examiner">The Baltimore Examiner</a>" was launched to compete with "The Sun". It was part of a national chain that includes "<a href="The%20San%20Francisco%20Examiner">The San Francisco Examiner</a>" and "<a href="The%20Washington%20Examiner">The Washington Examiner</a>". In contrast to the paid subscription "Sun", "The Examiner" was a free newspaper funded solely by advertisements. Unable to turn a profit and facing a deep recession, "The Baltimore Examiner" ceased publication on February 15, 2009.
Despite being located 40 miles northeast of <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, Baltimore is a major media market in its own right, with all major English language television networks represented in the city. <a href="WJZ-TV">WJZ-TV</a> 13 is a <a href="CBS">CBS</a> <a href="owned%20and%20operated%20station">owned and operated station</a>, and <a href="WBFF">WBFF</a> 45 (<a href="Fox%20Broadcasting%20Company">Fox</a>) is the flagship of <a href="Sinclair%20Broadcast%20Group">Sinclair Broadcast Group</a>, the largest station owner in the country. Other major television stations in Baltimore include <a href="WMAR-TV">WMAR-TV</a> 2 (<a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>), <a href="WBAL-TV">WBAL-TV</a> 11 (<a href="NBC">NBC</a>), <a href="WUTB">WUTB</a> 24 (<a href="TBD%20%28TV%20network%29">TBD</a>), <a href="WBFF">WBFF-DT2</a> 45.2 (<a href="MyNetworkTV">MyNetworkTV</a>), <a href="WNUV">WNUV</a> 54 (<a href="The%20CW">CW</a>), and <a href="WMPB">WMPB</a> 67 (<a href="PBS">PBS</a>). Baltimore is also served by low-power station <a href="WMJF-CD">WMJF-CD</a> 39 (<a href="Ion%20Television">Ion</a>), which transmits from the campus of <a href="Towson%20University">Towson University</a>.
Nielsen ranked Baltimore as the 26th-largest <a href="television%20market">television market</a> for the 2008–2009 viewing season and the 27th-largest for 2009–2010. Arbitron's Fall 2010 rankings identified Baltimore as the 22nd largest radio market.
